analyzed: purāṇeṣu iva sarga pratisarga vaṃśa manvantara vaṃśa anucaritam tad pratipādana pareṣu
translated: As in the Purāṇas, which are devoted to the exposition of creation, re-creation, genealogy, Manvantaras, and the history of dynasties.

analyzed: na tu tat vivakṣitam
translated: But that (Pradhāna, etc.) is not intended (to be the cause of the exposition).

analyzed: anya parāt api ca anya nimittam tat pratīyamānam abhyupeyeta
translated: And even if something else is intended (to be the cause of the exposition), that (Pradhāna, etc.) which is understood as the cause (of the exposition) would be accepted,

analyzed: yadi na māna antareṇa virudhyeta
translated: if it were not contradicted by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: asti tu vedānta śrutibhiḥ asya virodhaḥ iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that there is a contradiction with the Vedanta scriptures.

analyzed: tasmāt pramāṇa bhūtāt api yoga śāstrāt na pradhāna ādi siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, even from the Yoga scriptures, which are a means of valid knowledge, the existence of prakriti and other [principles] is not established.

original: ata eva yogaśāstraṃ vyutpādayitāha sma bhagavān vārṣagaṇyaḥ'guṇānāṃ paramaṃ rūpaṃ na dṛṣṭipathamṛcchati /
analyzed: atas eva yoga śāstram vyutpādayitā āha sma bhagavān vārṣagaṇyaḥ guṇānām paramam rūpam na dṛṣṭi patham ṛcchati
translated: For this very reason, the revered Varsaganya, who expounded the Yoga scriptures, said: The highest form of the gunas does not come within the range of vision.

analyzed: yat tu dṛṣṭi patha prāptam tat māyā eva su tucchakam
translated: But what comes within the range of vision is mere illusion, very trifling.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: yogam vyutpipādayiṣatā nimitta mātreṇa iha guṇāḥ uktāḥ
translated: The gunas are mentioned here by the one who wishes to expound Yoga merely as a cause.

analyzed: na tu bhāvataḥ
translated: But not as real entities.

analyzed: teṣām atāttvika tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are not true.

analyzed: aloka siddhānām api pradhāna ādīnām anādi pūrvapakṣa nyāya ābhāsa utprekṣitānām anuvādya tvam upapannam
translated: Even though prakriti and other [principles] are not established in common experience, it is appropriate for them to be referred to as imagined by fallacious arguments in the eternal prima facie position.

analyzed: tat anena abhisaṃdhinā āha etena sāṃkhya smṛti pratyākhyānena yoga smṛtiḥ api pradhāna ādi viṣaya tayā a pratyākhyātā draṣṭavyā iti
translated: With this intention, he says: By this refutation of the Samkhya Smriti, the Yoga Smriti, which has prakriti and other [principles] as its subject matter, should also be seen as refuted.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa antara ārambham ākṣipati nanu evam sati samāna nyāyatvāt iti
translated: He raises the question of beginning a different section: If that is so, then by the same reasoning, etc.

analyzed: samādhatte asti atra abhyadhikā āśaṅkā
translated: He replies: There is a greater doubt here.

analyzed: mā nāma sāṃkhya śāstrāt pradhāna sattā vijñāyi
translated: Let not the existence of primordial matter be known from the Sāṃkhya scriptures.

original: yogaśāstrāttu pradhānādisattā vijñāpayiṣyate bahulaṃ hi yogaśāstrāṇāṃ vedena saha saṃvādo dṛśyate /
analyzed: yoga śāstrāt tu pradhāna ādi sattā vijñāpayiṣyate bahulam hi yoga śāstrāṇām vedena saha saṃvādaḥ dṛśyate
translated: But the existence of primordial matter, etc. will be made known from the Yoga scriptures. For the Yoga scriptures are seen to agree with the Veda in many places.

analyzed: upaniṣad upāyasya ca tattva jñānasya yoga apekṣā asti
translated: And the knowledge of reality, which is the means to the Upaniṣads, depends on Yoga.

analyzed: na jātu yoga śāstra vihitam yama niyama ādi bahiraṅgam upāyam apahāya antaraṅgam ca dhāraṇā ādikam antareṇa aupaniṣada ātma tattva sākṣātkāraḥ udetum arhati
translated: Never can the realization of the Self taught in the Upaniṣads arise without the external means enjoined by the Yoga scriptures, such as the restraints and observances, etc., nor without the internal means such as concentration, etc.

original: tasmādaupaniṣadena tattvajñānenāpakṣaṇāt saṃvādabāhulyācca vedenāṣṭakādismṛtivadyogasmṛtiḥ pramāṇam /🔽tataśca pramāṇātpradhānādipratīternāśabdatvam /
analyzed: tasmāt aupaniṣadena tattva jñānena apakṣaṇāt saṃvāda bāhulyāt ca vedena aṣṭaka ādi smṛti vat yoga smṛtiḥ pramāṇam  tatas ca pramāṇāt pradhāna ādi pratīteḥ na aśabda tvam
translated: Therefore, because of the dependence on the knowledge of reality taught in the Upaniṣads and because of the abundance of agreement with the Veda, the Yoga Smṛti is a means of knowledge, like the Smṛti of the Aṣṭakā, etc.🔽And from that means of knowledge, the understanding of primordial matter, etc. is not unscriptural.

analyzed: na ca tat apramāṇam pradhāna ādau
translated: And it is not proper to say that it is not a means of knowledge regarding primordial matter, etc.,

analyzed: pramāṇam ca yama ādau iti yuktam
translated: but is a means of knowledge regarding the restraints, etc.

analyzed: tatra aprāmāṇye nyatra api anāśvāsāt
translated: For if it is not a means of knowledge in that case, there can be no confidence in it elsewhere.

original: yathāhuḥ'prasaraṃ na labhante hi yāvatkvacana markaṭāḥ /
analyzed: yathā āhuḥ prasaram na labhante hi yāvat kvacana markaṭāḥ
translated: As they say: 'As long as monkeys do not find an opportunity anywhere,

analyzed: na abhidravanti te tāvat piśācāḥ vā sva gocare
translated: they do not rush to their own domain, nor do the evil spirits.'

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: seyaṃ labdhaprasarā pradhānādau yogāpramāṇatāpiśācī sarvatraiva durvārā bhavedityasyāḥ prasaraṃ niṣedhatā pradhānādyabhyupeyamiti nāśabdaṃ 🔽pradhānamiti śaṅkārthaḥ /🔽sāiyamapyadhikāśaṅkātirdeśena nivartyate /
analyzed: sā iyam labdha prasarā pradhāna ādau yoga apramāṇa tā piśācī sarvatra eva durvārā bhavet iti asyāḥ prasaram niṣedhatā pradhāna ādi abhyupeyam iti na aśabdam  pradhānam iti śaṅkā arthaḥ  sā aiyam api adhikā āśaṅkā atirdeśena nivartyate
translated: This demon of the invalidity of Yoga with regard to Prakriti etc., once gained a foothold, would be irresistible everywhere. To prevent its spread, it is said that Prakriti etc. should be accepted. The meaning of the doubt is that Prakriti is not mentioned in the scriptures.🔽This doubt is also removed by indicating an additional reason.

analyzed: nivṛtti hetum āha artha eka deśa saṃpratipattau api iti
translated: The reason for the removal is stated: even when there is agreement on a part of the meaning.

analyzed: yadi pradhāna ādi sattā param yoga śāstram bhavet
translated: If the Yoga scriptures were concerned with the existence of Prakriti etc.,

analyzed: bhavet pratyakṣa vedānta śruti virodhena apramāṇam
translated: they would be invalid due to contradiction with the directly perceived Vedanta scriptures.

analyzed: tathā ca tad vihiteṣu yama ādiṣu api anāśvāsaḥ syāt
translated: And in that case, there would be no confidence even in the observances etc. enjoined by them.

analyzed: tasmāt na pradhāna ādi param tat
translated: Therefore, it is not about Prakriti etc.

analyzed: kintu tat nimittīkṛtya yoga vyutpādana param iti uktam
translated: But it is said to be concerned with teaching Yoga, taking that as the occasion.

analyzed: na ca aviṣaye prāmāṇyam viṣaye pi prāmāṇyam upahanti
translated: And invalidity in an object not within its scope does not undermine validity even in the object within its scope.

analyzed: nahi cakṣuḥ rasa ādau apramāṇam rūpe pi apramāṇam bhavitum arhati
translated: For the eye, being invalid with regard to taste, is not obliged to be invalid with regard to form also.

analyzed: tasmāt vedānta śruti virodhāt prādhāna ādiḥ asya aviṣayaḥ na tu aprāmāṇyam iti paramārthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the highest truth is that Prakriti etc. are not its object due to contradiction with the Vedanta scriptures, not that it is invalid.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: adhyātma viṣayāḥ santi sahasram smṛtayaḥ bauddha ārhata kāpālika ādīnām
translated: There are thousands of recollections belonging to the Buddhists, Arhats, Kapalikas, etc., which have as their object the internal self.

original: tā api kasmānna nirākriyanta ityata āhasatīṣvapīti /
analyzed: tāḥ api kasmāt na nirākriyante iti atas āha satīṣu api iti
translated: Why are they not refuted? To this he says: Even though they exist.

original: tāsu khalu bahulaṃ vedārthavisaṃvādinīṣu śiṣṭānādṛtāsu kaiścideva tu puruṣāpasadaiḥ paśuprāyairmlecchādibiḥ parigṛhītāsu vedamūlatvāśaṅkaiva
analyzed: tāsu khalu bahulam veda artha visaṃvādinīṣu śiṣṭa an ādṛtāsu kaiścid eva tu puruṣa apasadaiḥ paśu prāyaiḥ mleccha ādibiḥ parigṛhītāsu veda mūla tva āśaṅkā eva
translated: For in those [recollections], which often contradict the meaning of the Vedas, are not respected by the learned, and are accepted only by some base men who are like animals, barbarians, etc., there is no suspicion that they are based on the Vedas.

analyzed: na asti iti na nirākṛtāḥ
translated: Therefore they are not refuted.

original: tadviparītāstu sāṃkhyayogasmṛtaya iti tāḥ pradhānādiparatayā vyudasyanta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tad viparītāḥ tu sāṃkhya yoga smṛtayaḥ iti tāḥ pradhāna ādi para tayā vyudasyante iti arthaḥ
translated: But the recollections of the Sankhyas and Yogas are the opposite of that. Therefore they are rejected as being about prakriti and so on. This is the meaning.

analyzed: na sāṃkhya jñānena veda nirapekṣeṇa iti
translated: Not by the knowledge of the Sankhyas, which is independent of the Vedas.

analyzed: pradhāna ādi viṣayeṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: by [the knowledge] which has prakriti and so on as its object.

analyzed: dvaitinaḥ hi te sāṃkhyāḥ yogāḥ ca
translated: For they, the Sankhyas and Yogas, are dualists.

analyzed: ye pradhāna ādi para tayā tat śāstram vyācakṣate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: those who explain that scripture as being about prakriti and so on.

original: saṃkhyā samyagbuddhirvaidikī tayā vartanta iti sāṃkhyāḥ /
analyzed: saṃkhyā samyak buddhiḥ vaidikī tayā vartante iti sāṃkhyāḥ
translated: The Sankhyas are those who proceed by samkhya, which is right knowledge based on the Vedas.

analyzed: evam yogaḥ dhyānam upāya upeyayoḥ abheda vivakṣayā
translated: Similarly, yoga is meditation, with the intention of non-duality between the means and the goal.

analyzed: citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ hi yogaḥ tasya upāyaḥ dhyānam pratyaya ekāna tā
translated: For yoga is the cessation of the fluctuations of the mind, and meditation is the one-pointedness of the mind, which is the means to that [yoga].

original: etaccopalakṣaṇam /🔽anye 'pi yamaniyamādayo bāhyā āntarāśca dhāraṇādayo yogopāyā draṣṭavyāḥ /🔽etenābhyupagatavedaprāmāṇyānāṃ kaṇabhakṣākṣacaraṇādīnāṃ sarvāṇi tarkasmaraṇānīti yojanā /🔽sugamamanyat ////
analyzed: etat ca upalakṣaṇam  anye pi yama niyama ādayaḥ bāhyāḥ āntarāḥ ca dhāraṇā ādayaḥ yoga upāyāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ  etena abhyupagata veda prāmāṇyānām kaṇabhakṣa akṣacaraṇa ādīnām sarvāṇi tarka smaraṇāni iti yojanā  sugamam anyat
translated: And this is an illustration.

original: START / / /🔽na vilakṣaṇatvād asya tathātvaṃ ca śabdāt / / / /🔽avāntarasaṃgatimāhabrahmāsya jagato nimittakāraṇaṃ prakṛtiścetyasya pakṣasyeti /🔽codayatikutaḥ punariti /
analyzed: start  na vilakṣaṇa tvāt asya tathātvam ca śabdāt  avāntara saṃgatim āha brahma asya jagataḥ nimitta kāraṇam prakṛtiḥ ca ityasya pakṣasya iti  codayati kutas punar iti
translated: Other external and internal means of yoga such as the observances, restraints, etc., and the dhāraṇās, etc., should be understood.

analyzed: samāna viṣaya tve hi virodhaḥ bhavet
translated: By this, it is connected that all the reasonings and recollections of those who accept the authority of the Vedas, such as eating barley, the conduct of the tortoise, etc., are [to be understood]. The rest is easy to understand.

original: na cehāsti samānaviṣayatā /🔽dharmavadbrahmaṇo 'pi mānāntarāviṣayatayātarkyatvenānapekṣāmnāyaikagocaratvādityarthaḥ /🔽samādhattebhavedayamiti /🔽'mānāntarasyāviṣayaḥ siddhavastvavagāhinaḥ /🔽dharmo 'stu kāryarūpatvādbrahma siddhaṃ tu gocaraḥ //🔽'tasmātsamānaviṣayatvādastyatra tarkasyāvakāśaḥ /🔽nanvastu virodhaḥ /
analyzed: na ca iha asti samāna viṣaya tā 🔽dharma vat brahmaṇaḥ pi māna antara aviṣaya tayā atarkya tvena anapekṣa āmnāya eka gocara tvāt iti arthaḥ 🔽samādhatte bhavet ayam iti 🔽māna antarasya aviṣayaḥ siddha vastu avagāhinaḥ 🔽dharmaḥ stu kārya rūpa tvāt brahma siddham tu gocaraḥ 🔽tasmāt samāna viṣaya tvāt asti atra tarkasya avakāśaḥ 🔽nanu astu virodhaḥ
translated: Here is the Sanskrit-English alignment based on the Japanese translations:

original: tathāpi tarkādare ko heturityata āhayathā ca śrutīnāmiti /🔽sāvakāśā bahvayo 'pi śrutayo 'navakāśaikaśrutivirodhe tadanuguṇatayā yathā nīyante
analyzed: tathā api tarka ādare kaḥ hetuḥ iti atas āha yathā ca śrutīnām iti  sa avakāśāḥ śrutayaḥ na vakāśa eka śruti virodhe tad anuguṇa tayā yathā nīyante
translated: Still, what is the reason for the respect for reasoning? To this he says: And just as the many statements that have an occasion are interpreted in accordance with the one statement that has no occasion when there is a contradiction with it,

analyzed: evam anavakāśa eka tarka virodhe tad anuguṇa tayā śrutayaḥ guṇa kalpanā ādibhiḥ vyākhyānam arhanti iti arthaḥ
translated: in the same way, even many statements can be explained by assuming additional factors, etc., in accordance with the one reasoning that has no occasion when there is a contradiction with it. This is the meaning.

original: api ca brahmasākṣātkāro virodhitayānādimavidyāṃ nivartayan dṛṣṭenaiva rūpeṇa mokṣasādhanamiṣyate /
analyzed: api ca brahma sākṣātkāraḥ virodhitayā anādim avidyām nivartayan dṛṣṭena eva rūpeṇa mokṣa sādhanam iṣyate
translated: Moreover, the direct realization of Brahman, by removing the beginningless ignorance as a contradiction, is accepted as the means of liberation by the very seen form.

original: tatra brahmasākṣātkārasya mokṣasādhanatayā pradhānasyānumānaṃ dṛṣṭasādharmyeṇādṛṣṭaviṣayaṃ viṣayato 'ntaraṅgaṃ /
analyzed: tatra brahma sākṣātkārasya mokṣa sādhana tayā pradhānasya anumānam dṛṣṭa sādharmyeṇa adṛṣṭa viṣayam viṣayataḥ ntaraṅgam
translated: There, inference, which is the principal means of knowing Brahman, is more internal in its object than the verbal knowledge, which has as its object something not seen, by the similarity of what is seen.

analyzed: bahiraṅgam tu atyanta parokṣa gocaram śābdam jñānam
translated: But verbal knowledge is more external, having as its object something utterly hidden.

analyzed: tena pradhāna pratyāsattyā api anumānam eva balīyaḥ iti āha dṛṣṭa sādharmyeṇa ca iti
translated: Therefore, even by the proximity of the principal [means of knowledge], inference is stronger. He says: And by the similarity of what is seen.

original: api ca śrutyāpi brahmaṇi tarka ādṛta ityāhaśrutiriti /
analyzed: api ca śrutyā api brahmaṇi tarkaḥ ādṛtaḥ iti āha śrutiḥ iti
translated: Moreover, reasoning is respected even by scripture with regard to Brahman. He says: Scripture.

original: so 'yaṃ brahmaṇo jagadupādānatvākṣepaḥ punastarkeṇa prastūyate'prakṛtyā saha sārūpyaṃ vikārāṇāmavasthitam /
analyzed: saḥ yam brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādāna tva ākṣepaḥ punar tarkeṇa prastūyate prakṛtyā saha sārūpyam vikārāṇām avasthitam
translated: This objection to Brahman being the material cause of the world is again taken up through reasoning: The identity of the modifications with the primordial nature is established.

original: jagadbrahmasarūpaṃ ca neti no tasya vikriyā //
analyzed: jagat brahma sarūpam ca na iti no tasya vikriyā
translated: And the world is not identical with Brahman, therefore it is not a modification of Brahman.

analyzed: viśuddham cetanam brahma jagat jaḍam aśuddhi bhāj
translated: Brahman is pure consciousness, the world is inert and impure.

analyzed: tena pradhāna sārūpyāt pradhānasya eva vikriyā
translated: Therefore, because of its similarity with the primordial nature, the world is a modification of the primordial nature alone.

original: 'tathāhieka eva strīkāyaḥ sukhaduḥkhamohātmakatayā patyuśca sapatnīnāṃ ca caitrasya ca straiṇasya tāmavindato 'paryāyaṃ sukhaduḥkhaviṣādānādhatte
analyzed: tathā hi ekaḥ eva strī kāyaḥ sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka tayā patyuḥ ca sapatnīnām ca caitrasya ca straiṇasya tām avindata u paryāyam sukha duḥkha viṣādān ādhatte
translated: Thus, the same body of a woman, being of the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion, produces, without distinction, pleasure, pain, and dejection in her husband, her co-wives, and in Caitra, her paramour, who does not find her.

analyzed: striyā ca sarve bhāvāḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: And all the states of a woman have been explained.

original: tasmātsukhaduḥkhamohātmatayā ca svarganarakādyuccāvacaprapañcatayā ca jagadaśuddhamacetanaṃ ca /
analyzed: tasmāt sukha duḥkha moha ātma tayā ca svarga naraka ādi uccāvaca prapañca tayā ca jagat aśuddham acetanam ca
translated: Therefore, the world is impure and non-intelligent, being of the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion, and having a complex of high and low such as heaven, hell, etc.

analyzed: brahma tu cetanam viśuddham ca
translated: But Brahman is conscious and pure.

analyzed: niratiśaya tvāt
translated: Because it is unsurpassed.

original: tasmātpradhānasyāśuddhasyācetanasya vikāro jaganna tu brahmaṇa iti yuktam /
analyzed: tasmāt pradhānasya aśuddhasya acetanasya vikāraḥ jagat na tu brahmaṇaḥ iti yuktam
translated: Therefore, it is proper that the world is a modification of the impure and non-intelligent primordial nature, but not of Brahman.

original: ye tu cetanabrahmavikāratayā jagaccaitanyamāhustānpratyāhaacetanaṃ cedaṃ jagaditi /
analyzed: ye tu cetana brahma vikāratayā jagat caitanyam āhuḥ tān pratyāha acetanam ca idam jagat iti
translated: But those who say that the world is consciousness because it is a modification of conscious Brahman, to them he says, This world is insentient.

analyzed: vyabhicāram codayati nanu cetanam api iti  pariharati na svāmi bhṛtyayoḥ api iti
translated: He raises the objection of inconstancy: But is not the self also conscious?🔽He replies: No, even in the case of master and servant.

analyzed: nanu mā nāma sākṣāt cetanaḥ cetanā antarasya upakāṣīt
translated: But let the self not directly help another self.

analyzed: tad kārya karaṇa buddhi ādi niyoga dvāreṇa tu upakariṣyati iti atas āha niratiśayāḥ hi akartāraḥ cetanāḥ iti
translated: It will help through the instrumentality of the intellect, etc., which are its effects. To this he says: Conscious beings are without superiority, and inactive.

analyzed: upajana apāyavat dharma yogaḥ tiśayaḥ
translated: Superiority is the possession of qualities subject to increase and decrease.

analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ niratiśaya tvam  atas eva nirvyāpāra tvāt akartāraḥ
translated: The absence of that is being without superiority.🔽For this very reason, they are inactive, because they are without operation.

analyzed: tasmāt teṣām buddhi ādi prayoktṛ tvam api na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they also do not employ the intellect, etc.

original: codako 'nuśayabījamuddhāṭayatiyopīti /🔽abhyupetyāpātataḥ samādhānamāhatenāpi kathañciditi /🔽paramasādhānaṃ tu sūtrāvayavena vaktuṃ tamevāvatārayatina cetaradapi vilakṣaṇatvamiti /
analyzed: codakaḥ nuśaya bījam uddhāṭayati yopī iti  abhyupetya āpātataḥ samādhānam āha tena api kathañcid iti  parama sādhānam tu sūtra avayavena vaktum tam eva avatārayati na ca itarat api vilakṣaṇa tvam iti
translated: The objector reveals the seed of doubt: But even so...🔽Accepting it for the sake of argument, he gives a prima facie answer: Even so, somehow...🔽But the ultimate answer is with the part of the sutra. To present that, he introduces it: Nor is the other kind of difference...

analyzed: sūtra avayava abhisaṃdhim āha an avagamyamānam eva hi idam iti

analyzed: evam ghaṭa śarāva ādi ātmanā nānātvam yāvat bhavati tāvat mṛd ātmanā nānātvam bhavet
translated: Similarly, as long as there is diversity in the form of pot, jar, etc., there would also be diversity in the form of clay.

analyzed: saḥ yam niyamaḥ kārya kāraṇayoḥ aikāntikam bhedam upakalpayati
translated: This rule implies absolute difference between cause and effect.

analyzed: anirvacanīya tām vā kāryasya
translated: Or it implies the inexpressibility of the effect.

analyzed: parākrāntam ca asmābhiḥ prathama adhyāye tat
translated: That has been dealt with by us in the first chapter.

analyzed: āstām tāvat
translated: Let that be.

analyzed: tat etat yukti nirākṛtam anuvadantīm śrutim udāharati mṛttikā iti eva satyam iti
translated: He cites the scripture, which repeats what has been refuted by reasoning, saying Clay alone is true.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: na brahmaṇaḥ jīva bhāvaḥ kālpanikaḥ
translated: The state of the individual soul is not imaginary for Brahman.

analyzed: kintu bhāvikaḥ
translated: But it is real.

original: aṃśo hi saḥ / tasya karmasahitena jñānena brahmabhāva ādhīyata ityata āhasvayaṃ prasiddha hīti /
analyzed: aṃśaḥ hi saḥ tasya karma sahitena jñānena brahma bhāvaḥ ādhīyate iti atas āha svayam hi iti
translated: For that is a part of Brahman. By knowledge accompanied by action, the state of Brahman is imposed on it. To this he says It is well known by itself.

analyzed: svābhāvikasya anādeḥ iti
translated: Of what is natural and beginningless.

original: yaduktaṃ nānātvāṃśena tu karmakāṇḍāśrayo laukikaśca vyavahāraḥ setsyatīti /
analyzed: yat uktam nānātva aṃśena tu karmakāṇḍa āśrayaḥ laukikaḥ ca vyavahāraḥ setsyati iti
translated: It has been said that the conduct based on the section on ritual and worldly conduct will be established by the part of diversity.

analyzed: tatra āha bādhite ca iti
translated: Regarding that, he says If contradicted, etc.

original: yāvadabādhaṃ hi sarvo 'yaṃ vyavahāraḥ svapnadaśāyāmiva tadupadarśitapadārthajātavyavahāraḥ /🔽sa ca yathā jāgradavasthāyāṃ bādhakānnivartate evaṃ tattvamasyādivākyaparibhāvanābhyāsaparipākabhuvā śārīrasya brahmātmabhāvasākṣātkāreṇa bādhakena
analyzed: yāvadabādham hi sarvaḥ yam vyavahāraḥ svapna daśāyām iva tad upadarśita padārtha jāta vyavahāraḥ  sa ca yathā jāgrat avasthāyām bādhakāt nivartate evam tattvamasi ādi vākya paribhāvanā abhyāsa paripāka bhuvā śārīrasya brahma ātma bhāva sākṣātkāreṇa bādhakena
translated: For all this practical life is unobstructed as long as it lasts, like the practical life of the things shown in a dream.🔽And that is removed by the obstruction of the embodied soul's realization of the identity of Brahman and the self, which is brought about by the maturity of the practice of reflecting on the statements beginning with 'That thou art' (Chand.

analyzed: nivartate
translated: 6.8.7), just as it is removed by the obstruction of waking consciousness.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be objected:

original: 'yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūttat kena kaṃ paśyet'ityādinā mithyājñānādhīno vyavahāraḥ kriyākārakādilakṣaṇaḥ samyagjñānenāpanīyata iti na
analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśya iti ādinā mithyā jñāna adhīnaḥ vyavahāraḥ kriyā kāraka ādi lakṣaṇaḥ samyak jñānena apanīyate iti na
translated: By the statement 'When everything has become the self alone, by what and whom should one see?' (Br. 4.5.15), the practical life characterized by action, agent, etc., which depends on false knowledge, is removed by true knowledge.

analyzed: kintu avasthā bheda āśrayaḥ vyavahāraḥ vasthā antara prāptyā nivartate
translated: But the practical life based on the difference of states is removed by the attainment of another state.

analyzed: yathā bālakasya kāmacāra vāda bhakṣa tā upanayana prāptau nivartate
translated: Just as a child's behavior of eating with unrestricted movement is removed upon attaining the Upanayana (sacred thread ceremony).

original: naca tāvatāsau mithyājñānanibandhano bhavatyevamatrāpītyata āhana cāyaṃ vyavahārābhāva iti /
analyzed: na ca tāvatā asau mithyājñāna nibandhanaḥ bhavati evam atra api iti atas āha na ca ayam vyavahāra abhāvaḥ iti
translated: And it does not follow that it is based on false knowledge. The same is the case here also. To this he says: And this absence of practical life...

analyzed: kutas tat tvam asi iti brahma ātmabhāvasya iti
translated: Why? Because of the identity of Brahman and the self.

analyzed: na khalu etat vākyam avasthā viśeṣa viniyatam brahma ātmabhāvam āha jīvasya
translated: This statement does not declare the identity of the individual soul with Brahman as restricted to a particular state.

original: api tu na bhujaṅgo rajjuriyamitivat sadātanaṃ tamabhivadati /
analyzed: api tu na bhujaṅgaḥ rajjuḥ iyam itivat sadātanam tam abhivadati
translated: But rather, like the statement This is not a snake, it is a rope, it declares that [identity] to be eternal.

analyzed: api ca satya anṛta abhidhānena api etat eva yuktam iti āha taskara dṛṣṭāntena ca iti
translated: Moreover, this [identity] is proper even if expressed by means of true and false statements. He says this with the example of the thief.

analyzed: na ca asmin darśane iti
translated: And in this view,

original: nahi jātu kāṣṭhasya daṇḍakamaṇḍalukuṇḍalaśālinaḥ kuṇḍalitvajñānaṃ daṇḍavattāṃ kamaṇḍalumattāṃ bādhate /
analyzed: nahi jātu kāṣṭhasya daṇḍa kamaṇḍalu kuṇḍala śālinaḥ kuṇḍali tva jñānam daṇḍavat tām kamaṇḍalumat tām bādhate
translated: for the knowledge of the earring in a stick, water pot, and earring does not contradict the stickness, water potness, or earringness.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for that?

analyzed: teṣām kuṇḍala ādīnām tasmin bhāvika tvāt
translated: Because those earrings and so on exist in that [stick].

analyzed: tadvat iha api bhāvika gocareṇa aikātmya jñānena na nānātvam bhāvikam apavadanīyam
translated: In the same way, here too, the knowledge of identity, which has as its object what exists, does not contradict the existence of difference.

analyzed: nahi jñānena vastu apanīyate
translated: For an existent thing is not removed by knowledge.

analyzed: api tu mithyājñānena āropitam iti arthaḥ
translated: Rather, it is superimposed by false knowledge, is the meaning.

analyzed: codayati nanu ekatva ekānta abhyupagamaḥ iti
translated: He objects: If oneness is accepted as absolute...

analyzed: abādhita anadhigata asaṃdigdha vijñāna sādhanam pramāṇam iti pramāṇa sāmānya lakṣaṇa upapattyā pratyakṣa ādīni pramāṇa tām aśnuvate
translated: Perception and the other means of valid knowledge obtain the status of means of valid knowledge by the occurrence of the general definition of a means of valid knowledge, which is a means of valid knowledge is that which establishes a cognition that is free from contradiction, not known, and not doubtful.

original: ekatvaikāntābhyupagame tu teṣāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhedaviṣayāṇāṃ bādhitatvādaprāmāṇyaṃ prasajyeta /
analyzed: ekatva ekānta abhyupagame tu teṣām sarveṣām bheda viṣayāṇām bādhita tvāt aprāmāṇyam prasajyeta
translated: But if you maintain the doctrine of absolute identity, then all these [means of knowledge], which have difference for their object, would be contradicted, and so would be invalid.

analyzed: tathā vidhi pratiṣedha śāstram api bhāvanā bhāvya bhāvaka karaṇa iti kartavya tā bheda apekṣa tvāt vyāhanyeta
translated: And so also the injunctions and prohibitions of the scriptures would be contradicted, because they depend on the difference of the act to be done, the object to be accomplished, the agent, the means, and the manner of performance.

analyzed: tathā ca nāstikyam
translated: And so there would be atheism.

analyzed: eka deśa ākṣepeṇa ca sarva veda ākṣepāt vedāntānām api aprāmāṇyam iti abheda ekānta abhyupagama hāniḥ
translated: And by the rejection of one part [of the Veda], the whole Veda would be rejected, and so the Vedanta would be invalid. Thus there would be the loss of the doctrine of absolute non-difference.

original: na kevalaṃ vidhiniṣedhākṣepeṇāsya mokṣaśāstrasyākṣepaḥ svarūpeṇāsyāpi bhedāpekṣatvādityāhamokṣaśāstrasyāpīti /
analyzed: na kevalam vidhi niṣedha ākṣepeṇa asya mokṣa śāstrasya ākṣepaḥ svarūpeṇa asya api bheda apekṣa tvāt iti āha mokṣa śāstrasya api iti
translated: And not only is this doctrine of liberation rejected by the rejection of injunctions and prohibitions, but also by its own nature, because it depends on difference. Thus he says: The doctrine of liberation also...

analyzed: api ca asmin darśane varṇa pada vākya prakaraṇa ādīnām alīka tvāt tad prabhavam advaita jñānam asīcīnam bhavet
translated: Moreover, in this view, since letters, words, sentences, chapters, etc. are unreal, the knowledge of non-duality arising from them would be false.

analyzed: na khalu alīkāt dhūmaketana jñānam samīcīnam iti āha katham ca anṛtena mokṣa śāstreṇa iti
translated: For knowledge of smoke and a fire arising from what is unreal is not true. He says: And how can there be liberation through a false doctrine of liberation?

analyzed: pariharati atra ucyate iti
translated: He answers: To this we reply...

analyzed: yadi api pratyakṣa ādīnām tāttvikam abādhita tvam na asti
translated: Even though perception and the other [means of knowledge] do not have true and uncontradicted [validity],

analyzed: yukti āgamābhyām bādhanāt
translated: because they are contradicted by reasoning and scripture.

analyzed: tathā api vyavahāre bādhana abhāvāt sāṃvyavahārikam abādhanam
translated: Nevertheless, because there is no contradiction in conventional usage, it is not contradicted conventionally.

original: nahi pratyakṣādibhirarthaṃ paricchidya pravartamāno vyavahāre visaṃbādyate sāṃsārikaḥ kaścit /
analyzed: nahi pratyakṣa ādibhiḥ artham paricchidya pravartamānaḥ vyavahāre visaṃbādyate sāṃsārikaḥ kaścid
translated: For no one in the world who acts after determining an object by perception etc. is contradicted in conventional usage.

analyzed: tasmāt abādhanāt na pramāṇa lakṣaṇam atipatanti pratyakṣa ādayaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because there is no contradiction, perception etc. do not go beyond the definition of valid cognition.

analyzed: satya tva upapatteḥ iti
translated: Because the truth is possible.

analyzed: satya tva abhimāna upapatteḥ iti
translated: Because the conception of truth is possible.

analyzed: grahaṇaka vākyam etat
translated: This is the main sentence.

analyzed: vibhajate yāvat hi na satya ātma ekatva pratipattiḥ iti
translated: He analyzes: As long as there is no realization of the oneness of the true Self.

analyzed: vikārān eva tu śarīra ādīn aham iti ātma bhāvena putra paśu ādīn mama iti ātmīya bhāvena iti yojanā
translated: But the body etc. are modifications, and the son, cattle etc. are considered as mine, as belonging to the Self. This is the construction.

analyzed: vaidikaḥ ca iti
translated: And the Vedic.
This is the defense of the ritual section and the discourse on liberation.

analyzed: svapna vyavahārasya iva eti vibhajate yathā suptasya prākṛtasya iti
translated: As in the case of the usage in a dream, he analyzes: As in the case of an ordinary person who is asleep.

original: 'kathaṃ cānṛtena mokṣaśāstreṇa'iti yaduktaṃ tadanubhāṣya dūṣayatikathaṃ tvasatyeneti /
analyzed: katham ca anṛtena mokṣa śāstreṇa eti yat uktam tat anubhāṣya dūṣayati katham tu asatyena iti
translated: And what was said: How can liberation be taught by an untruth? - having quoted this, he criticizes: But how can it be by an untruth?

analyzed: śakyam atra vaktum
translated: Here it can be said:

analyzed: śravaṇa ādi upāyaḥ ātma sākṣātkāra paryantaḥ vedānta samutthaḥ pi jñāna nicayaḥ satyaḥ
translated: The aggregate of knowledge, beginning with hearing and ending with the direct realization of the self, which is based on the Vedanta, is also unreal.

analyzed: saḥ pi hi vṛtti rūpaḥ kārya tayā nirodha dharmā
translated: For that also is of the nature of modification, and is subject to cessation as an effect.

original: yastu brahmasvabhāvasākṣātkāro 'sau na kāryastatsvabhāvatvāt /🔽tasmādacodyametat kathamasatyātsatyotpāda iti /
analyzed: yaḥ tu brahma svabhāva sākṣātkāraḥ sau na kāryaḥ tad svabhāva tvāt  tasmāt acodyam etat katham asatyāt satya utpādaḥ iti
translated: But the direct realization of Brahman's nature is not an effect, because it is of the same nature as Brahman.🔽Therefore, this objection - how can the real arise from the unreal - is not valid.

original: yatkhalu satyaṃ na tadutpadyata iti kutastasyāsatyādutpādaḥ /
analyzed: yat khalu satyam na tat utpadyate iti kutas tasya asatyāt utpādaḥ
translated: For what is real does not arise. How then can it arise from the unreal?

analyzed: yat ca utpadyate tat sarvam asatyam eva
translated: And what does arise, all that is indeed unreal.

original: sāṃvyavahārikaṃ tu satyatvaṃ vṛttirūpasya brahmasākṣātkārasyeva śravaṇādīnāmapyabhinnam /
analyzed: sāṃvyavahārikam tu satya tvam vṛtti rūpasya brahma sākṣātkārasya iva śravaṇa ādīnām api abhinnam
translated: But the reality of the conventional is the same for the direct realization of Brahman in the form of modification, as it is for hearing and the other means.

original: tasmādabhyupetya vṛttisvarūpasya brahmasākṣātkārasya paramārthasatyatāṃ vyabhicārodbhāvanamiti mantavyam /
analyzed: tasmāt abhyupetya vṛtti svarūpasya brahma sākṣātkārasya paramārtha satyatām vyabhicāra udbhāvanam iti mantavyam
translated: Therefore, it should be understood that the objection is raised by assuming the ultimate reality of the direct realization of Brahman in the form of modification.

original: yadyapi sāṃvvahārikasya satyādeva bhayātsatyaṃ maraṇamutpadyate tathāpi bhayaheturahistajjñānaṃ vāsatyaṃ tato bhayaṃ satyaṃ jāyata ityasatyātsatyasyotpattiruktā
analyzed: yadi api sāṃvvahārikasya satyāt eva bhayāt satyam maraṇam utpadyate tathā api bhaya hetuḥ ahiḥ tad jñānam vā asatyam tatas bhayam satyam jāyate iti asatyāt satyasya utpattiḥ uktā
translated: Although death, which is real, arises from real fear, still the cause of fear, whether it is a snake or the knowledge of it, is unreal. Therefore, it is said that the real fear arises from the unreal.

original: yadyapi cāhijñānamapi svarūpeṇa sattathāpi na tajjñānatvena bhayaheturapi tvanirvācyāhirūṣitatvena /
analyzed: yadi api ca ahi jñānam api sva rūpeṇa sat tathā api na tad jñāna tvena bhaya hetuḥ api tu anirvācya ahiḥ ūṣita tvena
translated: Although the knowledge of a snake also exists in its own form, it is not the cause of fear by being knowledge, but rather by being superimposed on an indescribable snake.

analyzed: anyathā rajju jñānāt api bhaya prasaṅgāt jñāna tvena aviśeṣāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the absurd consequence of fear even from the knowledge of a rope, because there would be no difference in being knowledge.

analyzed: tasmāt anirvācya ahi rūṣitam jñānam api anirvācyam iti siddham asatyāt api satyasya upajanaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is established that even knowledge superimposed on an indescribable snake is indescribable. Thus, it is established that the real can arise even from the unreal.

analyzed: na ca brūmaḥ sarvasya āt asatyāt satyasya upajanaḥ
translated: And we do not say that the real always arises from the unreal.

original: yataḥ samāropitadhūmabhāvāyā dhūmamahiṣyā vahnijñānaṃ satyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yatas samāropita dhūma bhāvāyāḥ dhūma mahiṣyāḥ vahni jñānam satyam syāt
translated: Because the knowledge of fire from a smoke-cow, which is superimposed with the state of smoke, would be real.

original: nahi cakṣuṣo rūpajñānaṃ satyamupajāyata iti rasādijñānenāpi tataḥ satyena bhavitavyam /🔽yato niyamo hi sa tādṛśaḥ satyānāṃ yataḥ kutaścit kiñcideva jāyata iti /
analyzed: nahi cakṣuṣaḥ rūpa jñānam satyam upajāyate iti rasa ādi jñānena api tatas satyena bhavitavyam  yatas niyamaḥ hi sa tādṛśaḥ satyānām yatas kutaścid kiñcid eva jāyate iti
translated: For the knowledge of form from the eye does not arise as real, so it must also be real by the knowledge of taste and so on.🔽For that is the rule of the real, that something arises from somewhere.

analyzed: evam asatyānām api niyamaḥ yatas kutaścid asatyāt satyam kutaścid asatyam
translated: In the same way, there is a rule for the unreal as well, that the real arises from somewhere unreal and the unreal from somewhere.

analyzed: yathā dīrgha tva ādeḥ varṇeṣu samāropita tva aviśeṣe jyāni viraham avagacchanti satyam
translated: Thus, although the superimposition of length and so on on the letters is the same, they understand the absence of excessive length from the word 'ajina' as real.

analyzed: ajinam iti atas tu samāropita dīrgha bhāvāt jyāni viraham avagacchantaḥ bhavanti bhrāntāḥ
translated: But when they see the skin, they mistakenly think it lacks a bowstring because they superimpose the idea of length on it.

original: na cobhayatra dīrghasamāropaṃ prati kaścidasti bhedaḥ /
analyzed: na ca ubhayatra dīrgha samāropam prati kaścid asti bhedaḥ
translated: And there is no difference between the two cases with regard to the superimposition of length.

analyzed: tasmāt upapannam asatyāt api satyasya udayaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is established that the real can arise even from the unreal.

analyzed: nidarśana antaram āha svapna darśana avasthasya iti
translated: He gives another example: Like one who is in the state of seeing a dream.

original: yathā sāṃsāriko jāgradbhujaṅgaṃ dṛṣṭvā palāyate tataśca na daṃśavedanāmāpnoti /
analyzed: yathā sāṃsārikaḥ jāgrat bhujaṅgam dṛṣṭvā palāyate tatas ca na daṃśa vedanām āpnoti
translated: Just as one who is awake in the world, seeing a snake, flees from it and does not suffer the pain of a bite from it.

original: pipāsuḥ salilamālokya pātuṃ pravartate tatastadāsādya pāyaṃpāyamāpyāyitaḥ sukhamanubhavati /
analyzed: pipāsuḥ salilam ālokya pātum pravartate tatas tat āsādya pāyam pāyam āpyāyitaḥ sukham anubhavati
translated: One who is thirsty, seeing water, starts to drink it and, obtaining it, drinks it and is refreshed and experiences happiness.

analyzed: evam svapnāntike tad avastham sarvam iti asatyāt kārya siddhiḥ
translated: In the same way, all this is in the same state in a dream. Thus, the effect is established from the unreal.

analyzed: śaṅkate itat kāryam api anṛtam eva iti
translated: He doubts: That effect is also false.

analyzed: evam api na asatyāt satyasya siddhiḥ uktā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even so, the real is not established from the unreal, as stated.

analyzed: pariharati tatra brūmaḥ
translated: He replies: To that we say.

analyzed: yadi api svapna darśana avasthasya iti
translated: Even though one who is in the state of seeing a dream...

original: laukiko hi suptotthito 'vagamyaṃ bādhitaṃ manyate na tadavagatiṃ /
analyzed: laukikaḥ hi supta utthitaḥ vagamyam bādhitam manyate na tad avagatim
translated: For one who is awake in the world, what is perceived is considered false, not the perception itself.

original: tena yadyapi parikṣakā anirvācyarūṣitāmavagatimanirvācyāṃ niścinvanti tathāpi laukikābhiprāyeṇaitaduktam /
analyzed: tena yadi api parikṣakāḥ anirvācya rūṣitām avagatim anirvācyām niścinvanti tathā api laukika abhiprāyeṇa etat uktam
translated: Therefore, although the judges ascertain the cognition, which is enveloped by the inexpressible, to be inexpressible, this is said with reference to the intention of the world.

analyzed: atra antare laukāyatikānām matam apākaroti etena svapna dṛśaḥ vagati a bādhanena iti
translated: In the meantime, he refutes the opinion of the Lokāyatas with the words by this, by the non-contradiction of the cognition of the dreamer.

analyzed: yadā khalu ayam caitraḥ tārakṣavīm vyātta vikaṭa daṃṣṭrā karāla vadanām uttabdha bambhramat mastaka avacumbi lāṅgūlām ati roṣa aruṇa stabdha viśāla vṛtta locanām
translated: For when this Caitra, having taken on the body of an enemy in a dream,

analyzed: romāñca saṃcaya utphullam īṣaṇām sphaṭika acala bhitti pratibimbitām abhyamitrīṇām tanum āsthāya
translated: sees it reflected on the crystal wall, with its gaping, terrifying, sharp-toothed face, its bristling, whirling, head-kissing mane, its eyes wide and round with furious red rage,

original: svapne pratibuddho mānuṣīmātmanastanuṃ paśyati tadobhayadehānugatamātmānaṃ pratisaṃdadhāno🔽dehātiriktamātmānaṃ /
analyzed: svapne pratibuddhaḥ mānuṣīm ātmanaḥ tanum paśyati tadā ubhaya deha anugatam ātmānam pratisaṃdadhānaḥ  deha atiriktam ātmānam
translated: and its bristling, bristling whiskers, and when he awakens from the dream and sees his own human body, then, recollecting the self as present in both bodies,

analyzed: niścinoti
translated: he ascertains the self to be separate from the body.

analyzed: na tu deha mātram  tanmātra tve deha vat pratisaṃdhāna abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: But not the body alone.🔽For if it were just that, it would follow that there would be no recollection, as in the case of the body.

analyzed: katham ca etat upapadyeta yadi svapna dṛśaḥ vagatiḥ abādhitā syāt
translated: And how could this be possible if the cognition of the dreamer were not contradicted?

analyzed: tad bādhe tu pratisaṃdhāna abhāvaḥ iti
translated: But when that is contradicted, there is no re-unification.

analyzed: asatyāt ca satya pratītiḥ śruti siddha anvaya vyatireka siddhā ca iti āha tathā ca śrutiḥ iti
translated: And the cognition of the real from the unreal is established by scripture and by positive and negative concomitance. Thus he says: And thus scripture.

analyzed: tathā ākāra ādi iti
translated: And thus the form, etc.

analyzed: yadi api rekhā svarūpam satyam tathā api tat yathāsaṃketam asatyam
translated: Although the form of the lines is real, still it is unreal as per convention.

original: nahi saṃketayitāraḥ saṃketayantīdṛśena rekhābhedenāyaṃ varṇaḥ pratyetavyo 'pi tvīdṛśo rekhābhedo 'kāraṃ īdṛśaśca kakāra iti /
analyzed: nahi saṃketayitāraḥ saṃketayanti īdṛśena rekhābhedena ayam varṇaḥ pratyetavyaḥ tu īdṛśaḥ rekhābhedaḥ īdṛśaḥ ca kakāraḥ iti
translated: For the makers of conventions do not make conventions thus: This letter should be cognized by this kind of line difference, but this kind of line difference is a and this kind of line difference is k.

analyzed: tathā ca asamīcīnāt saṃketāt samīcīna varṇa avagatiḥ iti siddham
translated: And thus it is established that the correct cognition of the letter arises from the incorrect convention.

analyzed: yat ca uktam ekatva aṃśena jñāna mokṣa vyavahāraḥ setsyati
translated: And what was said: The usage of knowledge and liberation will be established by the aspect of oneness.

original: nānātvāṃśena tu karmakāṇḍāśrayo laukikaśca vyavahāraḥ setsyatīti /
analyzed: nānātva aṃśena tu karmakāṇḍa āśrayaḥ laukikaḥ ca vyavahāraḥ setsyati iti
translated: But the usage based on the Karmakāṇḍa and the worldly usage will be established by the aspect of manyness.

analyzed: tatra āha api ca antyam idam pramāṇam iti
translated: To that he says: And this is the final proof.

original: yadi khalvekatvānekatvanibandhanau vyavahārāvekasya puṃso 'paryāyeṇa saṃbhavatastatastadarthamubhayasadbhāvaḥ kalpyeta /
analyzed: yadi khalu ekatva anekatva nibandhanau vyavahārau ekasya paryāyeṇa saṃbhavataḥ tatas tad artham ubhaya sadbhāvaḥ kalpyeta
translated: If, indeed, the usages based on oneness and manyness were possible for one person without alternation, then the existence of both would be imagined for that purpose.

analyzed: na tu etat asti

analyzed: nahi eka tva avagati nibandhanaḥ kaścid asti vyavahāraḥ
translated: For there is no usage whatsoever that has the cognition of identity as its basis.

analyzed: tad avagateḥ sarva uttara tvāt
translated: Because that cognition is the highest of all.

analyzed: tathā hi tattvam asi iti aikātmya avagatiḥ samasta pramāṇa tad phalatā dvi ahārān apabādhamānā eva udīyate
translated: It is thus: The cognition of identity, 'That thou art,' arises without setting aside all the usages of the means of valid knowledge and their fruits.

analyzed: na etasyāḥ parastāt kiñcid anukūlam pratikūlam ca asti
translated: For this cognition there is nothing favorable or unfavorable,

analyzed: yad apekṣena
translated: in relation to which

analyzed: yena ca iyam pratikṣipyeta
translated: it would be rejected.

analyzed: tatra anukūla pratikūla nivāraṇāt na atas param kiñcid ākāṅkṣyam iti
translated: There, since it sets aside what is favorable and unfavorable, nothing else is to be desired after this.

analyzed: na ca iyam avagatiḥ ḍula kṣīra prāyā iti āha na ca iyam iti
translated: And this cognition is not like a mirage, he says: 'And this cognition is not useless.'

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: antyā cediyamavagatirniṣprayojanā tarhi tathā ca na prekṣāvadbhirupādīyeta /
analyzed: antyā ced iyam avagatiḥ niṣprayojanā tarhi tathā ca na prekṣāvadbhiḥ upādīyeta
translated: If this cognition is the last, then it is useless, and it would not be accepted by the wise.

analyzed: prayojanavat tve vā na antyā syāt iti atas āha na ca iyam avagatiḥ anarthikā akutas avidyā nivṛtti phala darśanāt
translated: Or, if it has a purpose, it would not be the last. To this he says: 'And this cognition is not useless. Why? Because it is seen to have the fruit of the cessation of ignorance.'

original: nahīyamutpannā satī paścādavidyāṃ nivartayati yena nāntyā syāt /
analyzed: nahi iyam utpannā satī paścāt avidyām nivartayati yena na antyā syāt
translated: For this cognition, when arisen, does not later remove ignorance, by which it would not be the last.

analyzed: kintu avidyā virodhi svabhāva tayā tad nivṛttyā ātmā eva udayate
translated: But rather, by its nature as opposed to ignorance, it arises itself as the cessation of that [ignorance].

analyzed: avidyā nivṛttiḥ ca na tad kārya tayā phalam api tu iṣṭa tayā
translated: And the cessation of ignorance is not the result by being its effect, but rather by being desired.

analyzed: iṣṭa lakṣaṇa tvāt phalasya iti  pratikūlam parācīnam nirākartum āha bhrāntiḥ vā iti
translated: Because the result is characterized by being desired.🔽To refute the contrary view, he says or error.

analyzed: kutas bādhaka iti
translated: Why? Because of contradiction.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: mā bhūt eka tva nibandhanaḥ vyavahāraḥ na eka tva nibandhanaḥ tu asti
translated: Let the usage not be based on oneness, but it is based on multiplicity.

analyzed: tat eva hi sakalām udvahati lokayātrām
translated: For that alone carries on the entire worldly life.

analyzed: atas tad siddhi artham anekatvasya kalpanīyam tāttvika tvam iti atas āha prāk ca iti
translated: Therefore, for its establishment, the reality of multiplicity should be imagined. To this he says but first (the usage is based on multiplicity).

analyzed: vyavahāraḥ hi buddhi pūrva kāriṇām buddhyā upapadyate
translated: For usage is possible for those who act with prior understanding, by understanding.

analyzed: na tu asyāḥ tāttvika tvena
translated: But not by its reality.

analyzed: bhrāntyā api tad upapatteḥ iti āveditam
translated: It has been stated that it is possible even by error.

analyzed: satyam ca tad avisaṃvādāt
translated: And it is true because of non-contradiction.

analyzed: anṛtam ca vicāra asaha tayā anirvācya tvāt
translated: And it is false because of being inexpressible due to not withstanding examination.
The final knowledge of oneness has the nature of contradiction due to being independent.

original: anekatvajñānasya ca pratiyogigrahāpekṣayā durbalatvena bādhyatvaṃ vadan prakṛtamupasaṃharatitasmādantyena pramāṇeneti /
analyzed: aneka tva jñānasya ca pratiyogi graha apekṣayā durbala tvena bādhya tvam vadan prakṛtam upasaṃharati tasmāt antyena pramāṇena iti
translated: And the knowledge of multiplicity has the nature of being contradicted due to being weaker by depending on the apprehension of its opposite. Stating this, he concludes the main point, saying therefore by the final means of knowledge.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: na vayam aneka tva vyavahāra siddhi artham aneka tvasya tāttvika tvam kalpayāmaḥ
translated: We do not imagine the reality of plurality in order to establish the usage of plurality.

analyzed: kintu śrautam eva asya tāttvika tvam iti codayati nanu mṛdāt iti
translated: But we point out that its reality is directly stated in the scriptures. He says: But is it not said in the scriptures that 'earth' etc. are real?

analyzed: pariharati na iti ucyate iti
translated: He replies: No, it is not said.

analyzed: mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntena hi kathañcid pariṇāmaḥ unneyaḥ
translated: For by the example of 'earth' etc., evolution is somehow suggested.

analyzed: na ca śakyaḥ unnetum
translated: But it cannot be suggested.

analyzed: mṛttikā iti eva satyam iti kāraṇa mātra satya tva avadhāraṇena kāryasya anṛta tva pratipādanāt
translated: Because by the determination of the truth of the cause alone in the statement Only 'earth' is true, the unreality of the effect is taught.

original: sākṣātkūṭasthanityatvapratipādikāstu santi sahasraśaḥ śrutaya iti na pariṇāmadharmatā brahmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: sākṣāt kūṭastha nitya tva pratipādikāḥ tu santi sahasraśas śrutayaḥ iti na pariṇāma dharma tā brahmaṇaḥ
translated: But there are thousands of scriptures directly teaching the immutability of Brahman. Therefore Brahman does not have the nature of undergoing evolution.

original: atha kūṭasthasyāpi pariṇāmaḥ kasmānna bhavatītyata āhana hyekasyeti /
analyzed: atha kūṭasthasya api pariṇāmaḥ kasmāt na bhavati iti atas āha na hi ekasya iti
translated: Now, if it is asked why there is no evolution even for the immutable, he says: For of one thing, etc.

analyzed: śaṅkate sthiti gati vat iti
translated: He raises the doubt: Like the state of rest and motion.

original: yathaikabāṇāśraye gatinivṛtti evamekasminbrahmaṇi pariṇāmaśca tadabhāvaśca kauṭasthyaṃ bhaviṣyata iti /🔽nirākarotina kūṭasthasyeti viśeṣaṇāditi /
analyzed: yathā eka bāṇa āśraye evam ekasmin brahmaṇi pariṇāmaḥ ca tad abhāvaḥ ca kauṭasthyam bhaviṣyate iti  nirākaroti na kūṭasthasya iti viśeṣaṇāt iti
translated: Just as there is cessation of motion in one arrow, so there will be evolution and absence of that, i.e. immutability, in Brahman, which is one.🔽He refutes: Not so, because of the qualification 'of the immutable'.

analyzed: kūṭastha nitya tā hi sadātanī svabhāvāt apracyutiḥ
translated: For the immutability of the immutable is the eternal non-deviation from its nature.

analyzed: sā katham pracyutyā na virudhyate
translated: How is it not contradicted by the fact of its being produced?

original: naca dharmiṇo vyatiricyate dharmo yena tadupajanāpāye 'pi dharmī kūṭasthaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na ca dharmiṇaḥ vyatiricyate dharmaḥ yena tad upajana apāye dharmī kūṭasthaḥ syāt
translated: And a property does not exist apart from the substance to which it belongs, so that the substance could remain unchangeable even when the property is produced or destroyed.

analyzed: bhedaḥ aikāntike gavāśva vat dharma dharmi bhāva abhāvāt
translated: For if there were absolute difference, there would be no relation of property and substance, as in the case of a cow and a horse.

original: bāṇādayastu pariṇāminaḥ sthityā gatyā ca pariṇamanta iti /
analyzed: bāṇa ādayaḥ tu pariṇāminaḥ sthityā gatyā ca pariṇamantaḥ iti
translated: But arrows, etc., which are subject to change, change by remaining and by motion.

original: api ca svādhyāyādhyayanavidhyāpāditārthavattvasya vedarāśerekenāpi varṇenānarthakena na bhavitavyaṃ kiṃ punariyatā jagato brahmayonitvapratipādakena 🔽vākyasaṃdarbheṇa /🔽tatra phalavadbrahmadarśanasamāmnānasaṃnidhāvaphalaṃ jagadyonitvaṃ samāmnāyamānaṃ tadarthaṃ sattadupāyatayāvatiṣṭhate nārthāntarārthamityāhanaca
analyzed: api ca svādhyāya adhyayana vidhi āpādita arthavat tvasya vedarāśeḥ ekena api varṇena anarthakena na bhavitavyam kim punar iyatā jagataḥ brahma yoni tva pratipādakena  vākya saṃdarbheṇa  tatra phalavat brahma darśana samāmnāna saṃnidhau aphalam jagadyoni tvam samāmnāyamānam tad artham sat tad upāya tayā avatiṣṭhate na artha antara artham iti āha na ca
translated: Moreover, the entire body of the Veda, which has been rendered fruitful by the injunction to study one's own Veda, should not be meaningless even by a single syllable. How much more so by this much, which teaches that the world has Brahman as its source?

analyzed: yathā brahmaṇi iti
translated: There, when the source of the world, which is fruitless, is being declared in proximity to the declaration of fruitful Brahman-vision, it remains as a means to that, as a contributory factor, not for any other purpose. He says: Nor is it like Brahman, etc.

analyzed: atas na pariṇāma para tvam asya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: therefore this does not refer to transformation.

original: tadananyatvamityasya sūtrasya pratijñāvirodhaṃ śrutivirodhaṃ ca codayatikūṭasthabrahmātmavādina iti /
analyzed: tad ananyatvam iti asya sūtrasya pratijñā virodham śruti virodham ca codayati kūṭastha brahma ātma vādinaḥ iti
translated: He raises the contradiction with the thesis and the contradiction with the scripture of the aphorism That is not different, saying: For one who maintains that Brahman is the unchanging Self,

analyzed: pariharati na
translated: He replies: No.

analyzed: avidyā ātmakaḥ iti
translated: It is of the nature of ignorance.

original: nāma ca rūpaṃ ca te eva bījaṃ tasya vyākaraṇaṃ kāryaprapañcastadapekṣatvādaiśvaryasya /
analyzed: nāma ca rūpam ca te eva bījam tasya vyākaraṇam kārya prapañcaḥ tad apekṣa tvāt aiśvaryasya
translated: Name and form are the seeds of that, and its manifestation is the proliferation of effects, because of the dependence of lordship on them.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavatina tāttvikamaiśvaryaṃ sarvajñatvaṃ ca brahmaṇaḥ kintvavidyopādhikamiti tadāśrayaṃ pratijñāsūtraṃ /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati na tāttvikam aiśvaryam sarvajña tvam ca brahmaṇaḥ kintu avidyā upādhikam iti tad āśrayam pratijñā sūtram
translated: This is what is said: Brahman's lordship and omniscience are not real, but are due to ignorance as a limiting adjunct. The proposition is based on that.
But the non-difference is based on reality.

analyzed: tena avirodhaḥ
translated: Therefore there is no contradiction.

analyzed: sugamam anyat  start  bhāve ca upalabdheḥ
translated: The rest is easily understood.🔽And because the effect is perceived when the cause exists.

original: kāraṇasya bhāvaḥ sattā copalambhaśca tasmin kāryasyopalabdherbhāvācca /
analyzed: kāraṇasya bhāvaḥ sattā ca upalambhaḥ ca tasmin kāryasya upalabdheḥ bhāvāt ca
translated: The existence and perception of the cause, from that the perception and existence of the effect.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati viṣaya padam viṣaya viṣayi param
translated: This is what is said: The word 'object' refers to both the object and the subject.

analyzed: viṣayi padam api viṣayi viṣaya param
translated: The word 'subject' also refers to both the subject and the object.

analyzed: tena kāraṇa upalambha bhāvayoḥ upādeya upalambha bhāvāt iti sūtra arthaḥ saṃpadyate
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the sutra becomes: 'Because of the perception and existence of the effect, there is the perception and existence of the cause.'

original: tathā ca prabhārūpānuviruddhabodhyena cākṣuṣeṇa na vyabhicāraḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca prabhā rūpa anuviruddha bodhyena cākṣuṣeṇa na vyabhicāraḥ
translated: And thus there is no fallacy in the visual perception of the red color, which is not contradictory to the object to be known.

analyzed: nā api vahni bhāva abhāva anuvidhāyi bhāva abhāvena dhūma bhedena iti siddham bhavati
translated: Nor is there fallacy in the distinction of smoke, which conforms to the existence and non-existence of fire. Thus it is established.

analyzed: tatra yathā ukta hetoḥ eka deśa abhidhānena upakramate bhāṣyakāraḥ itas ca kāraṇāt ananya tvam bheda abhāvaḥ kāryasya
translated: There, the author of the Bhāṣya begins with the statement of a part of the reason as stated, saying And for this reason also, the effect is not different, i.e., there is no difference.

analyzed: yatkāraṇam yasmāt kāraṇāt bhāvaḥ eva kāraṇasya iti
translated: Because existence itself is the cause.

analyzed: asya vyatireka mukhena gamaka tvam āha na ca niyamena iti
translated: He shows the inferential nature of this by the method of difference, saying And it is not invariably so.

analyzed: kākatālīya nyāyena anya bhāve
translated: By the principle of coincidence, something else is perceived when something else exists.

analyzed: na tu niyamena iti arthaḥ
translated: But it is not invariably so, is the meaning.

analyzed: hetu viśeṣaṇāya vyabhicāram codayati nanu anyasya bhāve pi iti
translated: He raises an objection to the qualification of the reason, saying But even when something else exists.

analyzed: ekadeśi matena pariharati na iti ucyate iti

analyzed: śaṅkayā eka deśi parihāram dūṣayitvā paramārtha parihāram āha atha iti
translated: Having refuted the reply of a certain school by raising an objection, he gives the reply according to the highest truth, saying If it be said.

analyzed: tat anena hetu viśeṣaṇam uktam
translated: By this, the qualification of the reason is stated.

analyzed: pāṭha antareṇa idam eva sūtram vyācaṣṭena kevalam śabdāt eva iti
translated: He explains this very sūtra with a different reading, saying Not merely from the word.

original: paṭa iti hi pratyakṣabuddhyā tantava evātānavitānāvasthā ālambyante /
analyzed: paṭaḥ iti hi pratyakṣa buddhyā tantavaḥ eva ātāna vitāna avasthāḥ ālambyante
translated: For by the cognition of perception, the threads themselves in the state of being stretched and woven are apprehended as the cloth.

analyzed: na tu tad atiriktaḥ paṭaḥ pratyakṣam upalabhyate
translated: But the cloth, which is different from that, is not perceived by perception.

analyzed: eka tvam tu tantūnām eka prāvaraṇa lakṣaṇa artha kriyā avacchedāt bahūnām api
translated: But the unity of the threads is due to the restriction of their operation by the character of being one covering, even though they are many.

analyzed: yathā eka deśa kāla avacchinnāḥ dhava khadira palāśa ādayaḥ bahavaḥ vanam iti
translated: Just as many things, such as dhavas, khadiras, palasas, etc., restricted by one place and time, are called a forest.

original: arthakriyāyāṃ ca pratyekamasamarthā apyanārabhyaivārthāntaraṃ kiñcinmilitāḥ kurvanto dṛśyante /
analyzed: arthakriyāyām ca pratyekam asamarthāḥ api an ārabhya eva artha antaram kiñcid militāḥ kurvantaḥ dṛśyante
translated: And in the case of an operation, even though they are individually incapable, they are seen to perform it by merely coming together without beginning any other thing.

analyzed: yathā grāvāṇaḥ ukhā dhāraṇam ekam
translated: Just as the stones hold up the cauldron.

analyzed: evam an ārabhya eva artha antaram tantavaḥ militāḥ prāvaraṇam ekam kariṣyanti
translated: In the same way, the threads, without beginning any other thing, will perform the single operation of covering by merely coming together.

original: naca samavāyādbhinnayorapi bhedānavasāyaḥ anavasāya iti sāṃpratama /
analyzed: na ca samavāyāt bhinnayoḥ api bheda anavasāyaḥ anavasāyaḥ iti sāṃpratam
translated: And it is not right to say that even in the case of two different things, there is no ascertainment of difference due to inherence; that there is no ascertainment.

analyzed: anyonya āśraya tvāt
translated: Because of mutual dependence.

original: bhede hi siddhe samavāyaḥ samavāyācca bhedaḥ /
analyzed: bhede hi siddhe samavāyaḥ samavāyāt ca bhedaḥ
translated: For when difference is established, there is inherence; and from inherence, difference.

analyzed: na ca bhede sādhana antaram asti
translated: And there is no other means of establishing difference.

analyzed: artha kriyā vyapadeśa bhedayoḥ abhede pi upapatteḥ iti upāditam
translated: It has been argued that even in the absence of difference, the difference in operation and designation is accounted for.

analyzed: tasmāt yat kiñcid etam

original: anayā ca diśā mūlakāraṇaṃ brahmaiva paramārthasat /
analyzed: anayā ca diśā mūla kāraṇam brahma eva paramārtha sat
translated: And in this way, Brahman alone, the primary cause, is ultimately real.

original: avāntarakāraṇāni ca tanvādayaḥ sarve 'nirvācyā evetyāhatathā ca tantuṣviti ////
analyzed: avāntara kāraṇāni ca tanu ādayaḥ sarve nirvācyāḥ eva iti āha tathā ca tantuṣu iti
translated: And all the secondary causes, such as threads and so on, are also inexpressible. Thus he says: And so, in threads, etc.

analyzed: start
translated: The author replies:

analyzed: sattvāt ca aparasya
translated: And because of the existence of another...

analyzed: vibhajate i taḥ ca iti
translated: He analyzes: And from this...

analyzed: na kevalam śrutiḥ
translated: And not only from scripture,

analyzed: upapattiḥ ca atra bhavati yat ca yat ātmanā iti
translated: but also from reasoning. Here is the reasoning: 'And what is of the nature of that...'

original: nahi tailaṃ sikatātmanā sikatāyāmasti yathā ghaṭo 'sti mṛdi mṛdātmanā /
analyzed: nahi tailam sikatā ātmanā sikatāyām asti yathā ghaṭaḥ sti mṛdi mṛd ātmanā
translated: Oil does not exist in sand as a sand-self, as a pot exists in clay as a clay-self.

original: pratyutpanno hi ghaṭo mṛdātmanopalabhyate /🔽naivaṃ pratyutpannaṃ tailaṃ sikatātmanā /
analyzed: pratyutpannaḥ hi ghaṭaḥ mṛdā ātmanā upalabhyate  na evam pratyutpannam tailam sikatā ātmanā
translated: For a present pot is perceived as having the nature of clay.🔽But present oil does not exist as a sand-self.

original: tena yathā sikatāyāstailaṃ na jāyata evamātmano 'pi jaganna jāyeta /
analyzed: tena yathā sikatāyāḥ tailam na jāyate evam ātmanaḥ u pi jagat na jāyeta
translated: Therefore, just as oil is not produced from sand, so the world would not be produced from the self.

analyzed: jāyate ca
translated: But it is produced.

analyzed: tasmāt ātmā ātmanā āsīt iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that the self existed as the self.

analyzed: upapatti antaram āha yathā kāraṇam brahma iti
translated: He states another reasoning: As the cause, Brahman...

original: yathā hi ghaṭaḥ sarvadā sarvatra ghaṭa eva nā jātvasau kvacitpaṭo bhavatyevaṃ sadapi sarvatra sarvadā sadeva na tu kvacitkadācidasadbhavitumarhatītyupapāditamadhastāt
analyzed: yathā hi ghaṭaḥ sarvadā sarvatra ghaṭaḥ eva nā jātu asau kvacid paṭaḥ bhavati evam sat api sarvatra sarvadā sat eva na tu kvacid kadācid asat bhavitum arhati iti upapāditam adhastāt
translated: For just as a pot is always and everywhere a pot only, and is never at any time a cloth anywhere, so what exists must always and everywhere be existent only, and cannot be non-existent anywhere at any time. This has been established below.

analyzed: tasmāt kāryam triṣu api kāleṣu sat eva

analyzed: kintu mokṣamāṇānām tattva jñāna utpādanāya

analyzed: yathā ca vedānta vākyebhyaḥ jagat upādānam brahma avagamyate
