translated: Therefore, let this be enough. This is the idea.

original: evamapi cetanaprayuktatvaṃ nābhyupeyeta yadi pramāṇāntaravirodho bhavet /
analyzed: evam api cetana prayukta tvam na abhyupeyeta yadi pramāṇa antara virodhaḥ bhavet
translated: And even so, the employment by a conscious being would not be accepted if there were contradiction by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: pratyuta śrutiḥ anuguṇatarā atra iti āha na ca evam sati iti
translated: On the contrary, the Veda is more favorable in this case. He says And in this way, etc.

analyzed: cakāreṇa suḥkha duḥkha ādi samanvaya lakṣaṇasya hetoḥ asiddha tvam samuccinoti iti āha anvaya ādi anupapatteḥ ca iti
translated: By the word ca (and), he includes the unestablishedness of the reason characterized by the concomitance of pleasure, pain, etc. He says And because of the non-applicability of positive and negative concomitance, etc.

original: āntarāḥ khalvamī suḥkhaduḥkhamohaviṣādā bāhyebhyaścandanādibhyo 'tivicchinnapratyayapravedanīyebhyo vyatiriktā adhyakṣamīkṣyante /
analyzed: āntarāḥ khalu amī suḥkha duḥkha moha viṣādāḥ bāhyebhyaḥ candana ādibhyaḥ ti vicchinna pratyaya pravedanīyebhyaḥ vyatiriktāḥ adhyakṣam īkṣyante
translated: These internal pleasures, pains, delusions, and despondencies are seen by perception to be distinct from external things like sandalwood, which are to be known by a very different kind of cognition.

original: yadi punareta eva suḥkhaduḥkhādisvabhāvā bhaveyustataḥsvarūpatvādhemante 'pi candanaḥ sukhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi punar ete eva suḥkha duḥkha ādi svabhāvāḥ bhaveyuḥ tatas sva rūpa tvāt hemante candanaḥ sukhaḥ syāt
translated: If, on the other hand, these were to have the nature of pleasure, pain, etc., then, because of being of the same nature, even sandalwood would be pleasure when touched.

analyzed: nahi candanaḥ kadācid acandanaḥ
translated: For sandalwood is never not-sandalwood.

analyzed: tathā nidāgheṣu api kuṅkuma paṅkaḥ sukhaḥ bhavet
translated: Similarly, even in the hot season, saffron paste would be pleasure.

analyzed: na hi asau kadācid a kuṅkuma paṅkaḥ iti
translated: For it is never not saffron paste.

original: evaṃ kaṇṭakaḥ kramelakasya sukha iti manuṣyādīnāmapi prāṇabhṛtāṃ sukhaḥ🔽syāt /
analyzed: evam kaṇṭakaḥ kra melakasya sukhaḥ iti manuṣya ādīnām api prāṇabhṛtām sukhaḥ  syāt
translated: Similarly, a thorn is pleasant for a camel, so it would be pleasant for humans and other living beings.

analyzed: na hi asau kāṃścid prati eva kaṇṭakaḥ iti
translated: For it is not a thorn for some only.

original: tasmādasukhādisvabhāvā api candanakuṅkumādayo jātikālāvasthādyapekṣayā sukhaduḥkhādihetavo na tu svayaṃ sukhādisvabhāvā iti ramaṇīyam /
analyzed: tasmāt asukha ādi svabhāvāḥ api candana kuṅkuma ādayaḥ jāti kāla avasthā ādi apekṣayā sukha duḥkha ādi hetavaḥ na tu svayam sukha ādi svabhāvāḥ iti ramaṇīyam
translated: Therefore, even though sandalwood, saffron, etc. have the nature of pleasure, etc., they are causes of pleasure, pain, etc. in dependence on the time of birth, state, etc., but they are not themselves of the nature of pleasure, etc. This is delightful.

original: tasmātsukhādirūpasamanvayo bhāvānāmasiddha iti nānena tadrūpaṃ kāraṇamavyaktamunnīyata iti /
analyzed: tasmāt sukha ādi rūpa samanvayaḥ bhāvānām asiddhaḥ iti na anena tad rūpam kāraṇam avyaktam unnīyate iti
translated: Therefore, the inherence of the form of pleasure, etc. in things is not established. Thus, the unmanifest, which has that form as its cause, is not inferred.

analyzed: tat idam uktam śabda ādi aviśeṣe ca bhāvanā viśeṣāt iti
translated: This is what is said: And even in the absence of difference in sound, etc., due to the difference in impression.

analyzed: bhāvanā vāsanā saṃskāraḥ tad viśeṣāt
translated: Impression means vāsanā, संस्कार, and due to the difference in that.

analyzed: karabha janma saṃvartakam hi karma karabha ucitām eva bhāvanām abhivyaniktim
translated: For the action that brings about birth as a camel manifests only the impression suitable for a camel.

analyzed: yathā asmai kaṇṭakāḥ eva rocante
translated: Just as thorns are agreeable to it.

analyzed: evam anyatra api draṣṭavyam
translated: The same should be seen in other cases as well.

analyzed: parimāṇāt iti sāṃkhyīyam hetum upanyasyati tathā parimitānām bhedānām iti
translated: Having presented the Sāṃkhya's reason because of finitude, he says and so on for finite differences.

original: saṃsargapūrvakatve hi saṃsargasyaikasminnadvaye 'saṃbhavānnānātvaikārthasamavetasya nānākaraṇāni saṃsṛṣṭāni kalpanīyāni /
analyzed: saṃsarga pūrvaka tve hi saṃsargasya ekasmin advaye saṃbhavāt nānātva eka artha samavetasya nānā karaṇāni saṃsṛṣṭāni kalpanīyāni
translated: For if conjunction is preceded by conjunction, then, because conjunction is impossible in the non-dual one, the various instruments that are conjoined and inhering in the same object as the various entities would have to be imagined.

analyzed: tāni ca sattva rajaḥ tamāṃsi eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And those are only sattva, rajas, and tamas. This is the idea.

analyzed: tat etat parimita tvam sāṃkhyīya rāddhānta ālocanena anaikāntikam iti dūṣayati sattva rajaḥ tamasām iti
translated: This finitude is inconclusive when considered in the light of the established doctrine of the Sāṃkhyas. Thus he criticizes it with the words of sattva, rajas, and tamas.

original: yadi tāvatparimitatvamiyattā /🔽sā nabhaso 'pi nāstītyavyāpako hetuḥ parimāṇāditi /
analyzed: yadi tāvat parimita tvam iyat tā  sā nabhasaḥ api na asti iti avyāpakaḥ hetuḥ parimāṇāt iti
translated: If finitude means having a limit,🔽then it does not exist even for space. Therefore the reason because of having a finite size is not universal.

original: atha na yojanādimitatvaṃ parimāṇamiyattāṃ nabhaso brūmaḥ kintvavyāpitām /
analyzed: atha na yojana ādi mita tvam parimāṇa miyat tām nabhasaḥ brūmaḥ kintu avyāpi tām
translated: Or if we do not say that finitude means having a limit, such as being measured by a yojana, but rather non-pervasiveness,

analyzed: avyāpi ca nabhaḥ tanmātra ādeḥ
translated: and space is not pervasive, then it is not an effect of the tanmātras etc.

analyzed: nahi kāryam kāraṇa vyāpi
translated: For an effect does not pervade its cause.

analyzed: kintu kāraṇam kārya vyāpi iti parimitam nabhaḥ tanmātra ādi avyāpi tvāt
translated: But a cause pervades its effect. Therefore space is finite because it is not pervaded by the tanmātras etc.

analyzed: hanta sattva rajaḥ tamāṃsi api na parasparam vyāpnuvanti
translated: But sattva, rajas, and tamas also do not pervade each other.

analyzed: na ca tattva antara pūrvaka tvam eteṣām iti vyabhicāraḥ
translated: And they do not have a different reality as their antecedent. Thus there is no fallacy of inconclusive reason.

original: nahi yathā taiḥ kāryajātamāviṣṭamevaṃ tāni parasparaṃ viśanti /
analyzed: nahi yathā taiḥ kārya jātam āviṣṭam evam tāni parasparam viśanti
translated: For just as the effects are pervaded by them, so those [sattva, rajas, and tamas] do not enter each other.

analyzed: mithas kārya kāraṇa bhāva abhāvāt  paraspara saṃsargaḥ tu āveśaḥ citi śaktau na asti
translated: Because there is no relation of cause and effect between them.🔽But there is no intermingling in the form of superimposition in the case of the power of consciousness.

analyzed: nahi citi śaṅktiḥ kūṭastha nityā taiḥ saṃsṛjyate
translated: For the power of consciousness, which is of the nature of pure consciousness, is not mixed up with them.

analyzed: tatas ca tad avyāpakāḥ guṇāḥ iti parimitāḥ
translated: And therefore, since they are not pervasive of that [consciousness], they are limited.

original: evaṃ citiśaktirapi guṇairasaṃsṛṣṭeti sāpi parimitetyanaikāntikatvaṃ parimitatvasya hetoriti /
analyzed: evam citi śaktiḥ api guṇaiḥ asaṃsṛṣṭā iti sā api parimitā iti anaikāntika tvam parimita tvasya hetoḥ iti
translated: And thus, since the power of consciousness is also not mixed up with the qualities, it too is limited. Thus, the reason of being limited is inconclusive.

analyzed: tathā kārya kāraṇa vibhāgaḥ pi samanvaya vat viruddhaḥ iti āha kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ tu iti
translated: Similarly, the distinction between cause and effect is also contradictory, like the doctrine of non-difference. He says: But the relation of cause and effect...

analyzed: start
translated: Beginning...🔽🔽

analyzed: pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: And because of activity.

original: na kevalaṃ racanābhedā na cetanādhiṣṭhānamantareṇa bhavantyapi tu sāmyāvasthāyāḥ pracyutirvaiṣamyaṃ /
analyzed: na kevalam racanā bhedāḥ na cetanā adhiṣṭhānam antareṇa bhavanti api tu sāmya avasthāyāḥ pracyutiḥ vaiṣamyam
translated: Not only do structures not occur without the control of an intelligent being, but also the departure from the state of equilibrium is inequality.

analyzed: tathā ca yat udbhūtam balīyaḥ tad aṅgi abhibhūtam ca
translated: And thus, that which is predominant due to being manifest overpowers the other.

analyzed: tad anuguṇa tayā sthitam aṅgam
translated: And the subordinate remains in accordance with that [predominant factor].

original: evaṃ hi guṇapradhānabhāve satyasya mahadādau kārye kā pravṛttiḥ /
analyzed: evam hi guṇa pradhāna bhāve satyasya mahat ādau kārye kā pravṛttiḥ
translated: Thus, when there is a relation of principal and secondary in this way, what is the activity of that [consciousness] in the effect such as Mahat and so on?

analyzed: sā api cetanā adhiṣṭhānam eva gamayati
translated: And that [activity] also indicates the control of an intelligent being.

original: na hi cetanādhiṣṭhānamantareṇa mṛtpiṇḍe pradhāne 'ṅgabhāvena cakradaṇḍasalilasūtrādayo 'vatiṣṭhante /
analyzed: na hi cetanā adhiṣṭhānam antareṇa mṛd piṇḍe pradhāne ṅga bhāvena cakra daṇḍa salila sūtra ādayaḥ vatiṣṭhante
translated: For without the control of an intelligent being, the lump of clay, the rod, the water, the thread, and so on, do not remain in the condition of subordinate members in the principal matter.

original: tasmātpravṛtterapi cetanādhiṣṭhānasiddhiriti 'śaktitaḥ pravṛtteśca'ityayamapi hetuḥ sāṃkhyīyo viruddha evetyuktaṃ vakroktyā /
analyzed: tasmāt pravṛtteḥ api cetanā adhiṣṭhāna siddhiḥ iti śaktitaḥ pravṛtteḥ ca eti ayam api hetuḥ sāṃkhyīyaḥ viruddhaḥ evā iti uktam vakroktyā
translated: Therefore, from activity also, the existence of an intelligent controller is established. Thus, the Sāṃkhya reason 'because of activity from potentiality' is also contradictory, as stated indirectly.

analyzed: atra sāṃkhyaḥ codayati nanu cetanasya api pravṛttiḥ iti
translated: Here, the Sāṃkhya objects: But there is activity even for the intelligent one.

original: ayamabhiprāyaḥtvayā kilaupaniṣadenāsmaddhetūn dūṣayitvā kevalasya cetanasyaivānyanirapekṣasya jagadupādānatvaṃ nimittatvaṃ ca samarthanīyam
analyzed: ayam abhiprāyaḥ tvayā kila aupaniṣadena asmad hetūn dūṣayitvā kevalasya cetanasya eva anya nirapekṣasya jagat upādāna tvam nimitta tvam ca samarthanīyam
translated: The idea is this: You, the Upaniṣadic proponent, having refuted our reasons, must establish that only the intelligent one, independent of anything else, is the material cause and the efficient cause of the world.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: kevalasya cetanasya pravṛtteḥ dṛṣṭānta dharmiṇī anupalabdheḥ iti
translated: Because the activity of only the intelligent one is not observed in the example-subject.

original: aupaniṣadastu cetanahetukāṃ tāvadeṣa sāṃkhyaḥ pravṛttimabhyupagacchatu paścāt svapakṣamata eva samādhāsyāmītyabhisaṃdhimānāhasatyametat /
analyzed: aupaniṣadaḥ tu cetana hetukām tāvat eṣa sāṃkhyaḥ pravṛttim abhyupagacchatu paścāt sva pakṣam atas eva samādhāsyāmi iti abhisaṃdhim ānāha satyam etat
translated: But the Upaniṣadic proponent, thinking that the Sāṃkhya will first accept that activity is caused by an intelligent being, and then will later establish his own position, says: This is true.

analyzed: na kevalasya cetanasya pravṛttiḥ dṛṣṭā iti
translated: There is no activity of only the intelligent one observed.

analyzed: sāṃkhyaḥ āha na tu acetana saṃyuktasya iti
translated: The Sāṅkhya says: Not of the one connected with the nonintelligent.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ aupaniṣada pakṣam vyāvartayati
translated: The word tu (not) sets aside the view of the Upaniṣads.

original: acetanāśrayaiva sarvā pravṛttirdṛśyate na tu cetanāśrayā kācidapi /
analyzed: acetana āśrayā eva sarvā pravṛttiḥ dṛśyate na tu cetanā āśrayā kācid api
translated: All activity is seen to be based on the nonintelligent, not on the intelligent at all.

analyzed: tasmāt na cetanasya jagat sarjane pravṛttiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that the intelligent one does not engage in the creation of the world.

analyzed: atra aupaniṣadaḥ gūḍha abhisaṃdhiḥ praśna pūrvakam vimṛśati kim punar atra iti
translated: Here, the Upaniṣadic adherent, with a hidden intention, reflects with a question: What is meant here?

analyzed: atra antare sāṃkhyaḥ brūte nanu yasmin iti
translated: In the meantime, the Sāṅkhya says: Is it not that in which?

original: na tāvaccetanaḥ pravṛtyāśrayatayā tatprayojakatayā vā pratyakṣamīkṣyate /
analyzed: na tāvat cetanaḥ pravṛti āśraya tayā tad prayojaka tayā vā pratyakṣam īkṣyate
translated: First of all, the intelligent one is not seen by perception as the basis of activity or as its cause.

analyzed: kevalam pravṛttiḥ tad āśrayaḥ ca acetanaḥ deha ratha ādiḥ pratyakṣeṇa pratīyate
translated: Only activity and its basis, the nonintelligent body, chariot, etc., are cognized by perception.

analyzed: tatra acetanasya pravṛttiḥ tad nimittā eva na tu cetana nimittā
translated: There, the activity of the nonintelligent is caused by that alone, not by the intelligent one.

original: sadbhāvamātraṃ tu tatra cetanasya gamyate rathādivailakṣaṇyājjīvaddehasya /
analyzed: sadbhāva mātram tu tatra cetanasya gamyate ratha ādi vailakṣaṇyāt jīvat dehasya
translated: But the mere existence of the intelligent one is understood there, due to the difference from a chariot, etc., of the living body.

analyzed: na ca sadbhāva mātreṇa kāraṇa tva siddhiḥ
translated: And mere existence does not establish causality.

original: mā bhūdākāśa utpattimatāṃ ghaṭādīnāṃ nimittakāraṇamasti hi sarvatreti /
analyzed: mā bhūt ākāśaḥ utpattimatām ghaṭa ādīnām nimitta kāraṇam asti hi sarvatra iti
translated: Let space not be the material cause of things produced such as pots, etc. It is present everywhere.

original: tadanena dehātirikte satyapi cetane tasya na pravṛttiṃ prati nimittabhāvo 'stītyuktam /
analyzed: tat anena deha atirikte sati api cetane tasya na pravṛttim prati nimitta bhāvaḥ sti iti uktam
translated: By this it is said that even when there is a conscious being other than the body, it does not have the nature of being a cause for its activity.

original: yataścāsya na pravṛttihetubhāvo 'sti ata eva pratyakṣe dehe sati pravṛttidarśanādasati cādarśanāddehasyaiva caitanyamiti laukāyatikāḥ pratipannāḥ /
analyzed: yatas ca asya na pravṛtti hetu bhāvaḥ sti atas eva pratyakṣe dehe sati pravṛtti darśanāt asati ca adarśanāt dehasya eva caitanyam iti laukāyatikāḥ pratipannāḥ
translated: And since it is not the cause of activity, therefore the Lokāyatas have accepted that consciousness belongs to the body itself, because activity is seen when the body is present and is not seen when it is absent.

original: tathā ca na cidātmanimittā pravṛttiriti siddham /
analyzed: tathā ca na cit ātma nimittā pravṛttiḥ iti siddham
translated: And thus it is established that activity does not have consciousness as its cause.🔽Therefore, the creation or activity of the world is not established to have consciousness as its cause, this is the reply of the Upaniṣadic scholar.

original: tasmānna racanāyāḥ pravṛttervā cidātmakāraṇatvasiddhirjagata iti aupaniṣadaḥ pariharatitadabhidhīyatena brūma iti /
analyzed: tasmāt na racanāyāḥ pravṛtteḥ vā cit ātma kāraṇatva siddhiḥ jagataḥ iti aupaniṣadaḥ pariharati tat abhidhīyatena brūmaḥ iti
translated: It is said: We do not say this.

original: na tāvat pratyakṣānumānāgamasiddhaḥ śārīro vā paramātmā vāsmābhiridānīṃ🔽sādhanīyaḥ /
analyzed: na tāvat pratyakṣa anumāna āgama siddhaḥ śārīraḥ vā paramātmā vā asmābhiḥ idānīm  sādhanīyaḥ
translated: The embodied self or the supreme self is not to be established by us now through perception, inference or scripture.

analyzed: kevalam asya pravṛtti prati kāraṇa tvam vaktavyam
translated: Only its nature as the cause of activity is to be stated.

original: tatra mṛtaśarīre vā rathādau vānadhiṣṭhite cetanena pravṛtteradarśanāt tadviparyaye ca pravṛttidarśanādanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ cetanahetukatvaṃ
analyzed: tatra mṛta śarīre vā ratha ādau vā anadhiṣṭhite cetanena pravṛtteḥ adarśanāt tad viparyaye ca pravṛtti darśanāt anvaya vyatirekābhyām cetana hetuka tvam
translated: There, because activity is not seen in a dead body or in an inanimate chariot, and because activity is seen when it is the opposite, by positive and negative concomitance, it is established that activity has a conscious being as its cause.

analyzed: na tu cetana sadbhāva mātreṇa
translated: But not merely by the existence of consciousness.

analyzed: yena atiprasaṅgaḥ bhavet
translated: By which there would be an overextension.

analyzed: bhūta caitanikānām api cedanā adhiṣṭhānāt acetanānām pravṛttiḥ iti atra avivādaḥ iti āha laukāyatikānām api iti
translated: And there is no dispute that even for the materialists, the operation of insentient things is without the control of consciousness. Thus he says even for the materialists.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: dehaḥ svayaṃ cetanaḥ karacaraṇādimān svavyāpāreṇa pravartayatīti yuktaṃ /
analyzed: dehaḥ svayam cetanaḥ kara caraṇa ādimān sva vyāpāreṇa pravartayati iti yuktam
translated: It is reasonable that the body itself, which is sentient and has hands, feet, etc., operates by its own activity.

original: na tu tadatiriktaḥ kūṭasthanityaścetano vyāpārarahito jñānaikasvabhāvaḥ pravṛttyabhāvāt pravartako yukta iti codayatinanu taveti /
analyzed: na tu tad atiriktaḥ kūṭastha nityaḥ cetanaḥ vyāpāra rahitaḥ jñāna eka svabhāvaḥ pravṛtti abhāvāt pravartakaḥ yuktaḥ iti codayati nanu tava iti
translated: But it is not reasonable that an additional, immutable, eternal, sentient being, devoid of activity, whose sole nature is knowledge, is the instigator because of the absence of operation. Thus he objects: But for you, how is it reasonable that an insentient thing is the instigator?

analyzed: pariharati na
translated: He replies: No.

analyzed: ayaskānta vat rūpa ādi vat ca iti
translated: Like a magnet and like form, etc.

analyzed: yathā ca rūpa ādayaḥ iti
translated: And like form, etc.

original: sāṃkhyānāṃ hi svadeśasthā rūpādaya indriyaṃ vikurvate /
analyzed: sāṃkhyānām hi sva deśa sthāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ indriyam vikurvate
translated: For the Samkhyas, form, etc. transform the sense organ while remaining in their own place.

original: tena tadindrayamarthaṃ prāptamarthākāreṇa pariṇamata iti sthitiḥ /
analyzed: tena tat indrayam artham prāptam artha ākāreṇa pariṇamate iti sthitiḥ
translated: Therefore, the sense organ, having reached the object, transforms into the form of the object - this is the position.

analyzed: saṃprati codakaḥ sva abhiprāyam āviṣkaroti eka tvāt iti
translated: Now the objector reveals his own intention: Because of oneness.

original: yeṣāmacetanaṃ cetanaṃ cāsti teṣāmetadyujyate vaktuṃ cetanādhiṣṭhitamacetanaṃ pravartata iti /
analyzed: yeṣām acetanam cetanam ca asti teṣām etat yujyate vaktum cetanā dhiṣṭhitam acetanam pravartate iti
translated: For those who have both insentient and sentient [principles], it is reasonable to say that an insentient thing operates when controlled by a sentient [principle].

analyzed: yathā yoginām īśvara vādinām  yeṣām tu cetanā atiriktam na asti advaita vādinām
translated: As in the case of the Yogis and the followers of Īśvara.🔽But for those who do not admit anything other than consciousness, the followers of non-duality,

original: teṣāṃ pravartyābhāve kaṃ prati pravartakatvaṃ cetanasyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām pravartya abhāve kam prati pravartaka tvam cetanasya iti arthaḥ
translated: what is the use of the instigation of consciousness when there is no instigated?

analyzed: pariharati na avidyā iti
translated: He answers: Not so, because of ignorance.

original: kāraṇabhūtayā layalakṣaṇayāvidyayā prāksargopacitena ca vikṣepasaṃskāreṇa yat pratyupasthāpitaṃ nāmarūpaṃ tadeva māyā /
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtayā laya lakṣaṇayā avidyayā prāc sarga upacitena ca vikṣepa saṃskāreṇa yat pratyupasthāpitam nāma rūpam tat eva māyā
translated: The name-and-form that is presented by ignorance in the form of attachment, which is a cause, and by the impressions of distraction accumulated before creation, that itself is Māyā.

analyzed: tad āveśena asya codyasya asakṛt prayukta tvāt

original: aṅgitvānupapattilakṣaṇo doṣastāvanna bhavadbhiḥ śakyaḥ parihartumiti vakṣyāmaḥ /🔽abhyupagamyāpyasyādoṣatvamucyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: aṅgitva anupapatti lakṣaṇaḥ doṣaḥ tāvat na bhavadbhiḥ śakyaḥ parihartum iti vakṣyāmaḥ  abhyupagamya api asya adoṣa tvam ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: We shall show that the fault consisting in the impossibility of being an accessory cannot be avoided by you.🔽The meaning is that even if we admit it, we say it is not a fault.

analyzed: saṃprati aṅgitva anupapattim upapādayati vaiṣamya upagama yogyāḥ api iti  start
translated: Now he explains the impossibility of being an accessory, saying even though capable of being brought into a state of inequality.

analyzed: vipratiṣedhāt ca asamañjasam
translated: And it is incoherent because of contradictions.

analyzed: kvacid sapta indriyāṇi iti
translated: In some places, there are seven sense faculties.

analyzed: tvac mātram eva hi buddhīndriyam aneka rūpa ādi grahaṇa samartham ekam
translated: For the skin alone is a single sense faculty capable of grasping multiple forms and so on.

analyzed: karmendriyāṇi pañca
translated: The faculties of action are five.

analyzed: saptamam ca manaḥ iti sapta indriyāṇi
translated: And the seventh is the mind, so there are seven sense faculties.

analyzed: kvacid trīṇi antaḥkaraṇāni
translated: In some places, there are three internal organs.

analyzed: buddhiḥ ahaṅkāraḥ manaḥ iti
translated: Intellect, ego, and mind.

analyzed: kvacid ekaṃbuddhiḥ iti
translated: In some places, there is one, the intellect.

analyzed: śeṣam atirohita artham
translated: The rest is of self-evident meaning.

analyzed: atra āha sāṃkhyaḥ nanu aupaniṣadānām api iti  tapya tāpaka bhāvaḥ tāvat ekasmin na upapadyate
translated: Here, the Sāṃkhya says: But for the Upaniṣads also...🔽The relation of the heated and the heater is not possible in one thing.

analyzed: nahi tapiḥ astiḥ iva kartṛ stha bhāvakaḥ  kintu paciḥ iva karma stha bhāvakaḥ
translated: For the heated is not a state-possessor residing in the agent, like the heater.🔽But rather, like the cooked, it is a state-possessor residing in the action.

analyzed: para samaveta kriyā phala śāli ca karma
translated: And an action is that which produces the result of an action inherent in another.

original: tathā ca tapyena karmaṇā tāpakasamavetakriyāphalaśālinā tāpakādanyena bhavitavyam /🔽ananyatve caitrasyeva gantuḥ svasamavetagamanakriyāphalanagaraprāptiśālino 'pyakarmatvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tathā ca tapyena karmaṇā tāpaka samaveta kriyā phala śālinā tāpakāt anyena bhavitavyam  ananya tve caitrasya iva gantuḥ sva samaveta gamana kriyā phala nagara prāpti śālinaḥ upi akarma tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And thus, by the act of being heated, which is productive of the result of the action inherent in the heater, there must be something other than the heater.🔽And if there were no difference, then, just as the goer Caitra, who is productive of the result of the action of going inherent in himself, would not be an agent, so also the object to be heated would not be an object of heating.

original: anyatve tu tapyasya tāpakāccaitrasamavetagamanakriyāphalabhājo gamyasyeva nagarasya tapyatvopapattiḥ /
analyzed: anya tve tu tapyasya tāpakāt caitra samaveta gamana kriyā phala bhājaḥ gamyasya iva nagarasya tapya tva upapattiḥ
translated: But if there were difference, then, just as the city, which is the object to be reached and is productive of the result of the action of going inherent in Caitra, is the object to be reached, so also the object to be heated is rightly the object of heating.

analyzed: tasmāt abhede tapya tāpaka bhāvaḥ na upapadyate iti
translated: Therefore, the relation of the object to be heated and the heater is not possible if there is non-difference.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram āha yadi ca iti
translated: He states another objection: If, on the other hand, the object to be heated were different from the heater, then it would be like the city, the object to be reached, and would not be the object to be heated.

original: nahi svabhāvādbhāvo viyojituṃ śakya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nahi svabhāvāt bhāvaḥ viyojitum śakyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that an entity cannot be separated from its nature.

original: jaladheśca vīcitaraṅgaphenādayaḥ svabhāvāḥ santa āvirbhāvatirobhāvadharmāṇo na tu tairjaladhiḥ kadācidapi mucyate /
analyzed: jaladheḥ ca vīci taraṅga phena ādayaḥ svabhāvāḥ santaḥ āvirbhāva tirobhāva dharmāṇaḥ na tu taiḥ jaladhiḥ kadācid api mucyate
translated: And the waves, ripples, foam, etc. of the ocean, which are its inherent properties, have the nature of appearing and disappearing, but the ocean is never devoid of them.

analyzed: na kevalam karma bhāvāt tapyasya tāpakāt anya tvam api tu anubhava siddham eva iti āha prasiddhaḥ ca ayam iti
translated: He says that the difference of the object to be heated from the heater is not only due to the nature of action, but is also established by experience.

analyzed: tathā hi arthaḥ pi upārjana rakṣaṇa kṣaya rāga vṛddhi hiṃsā doṣa darśanāt anarthaḥ san arthinam dunoti
translated: For thus: Wealth, even, becomes a source of pain to the seeker of wealth, by reason of the evils of acquisition, protection, loss, attachment, increase, and injury.

analyzed: tapyaḥ tāpakaḥ ca arthaḥ
translated: And that which is to be heated is the object to be heated, and that which heats is the object that heats.

analyzed: tau ca imau loke pratīta bhedau
translated: And these two are well known in the world to be different.

analyzed: abhede ca dūṣaṇāni uktāni
translated: And the objections urged against non-difference are (also applicable).

original: tatkathamekasminnadvaye bhavitumarhata ityarthaḥ /🔽tadevamaupaniṣadaṃ matamasamañjasamuktvā sāṃkhyaḥ svapakṣe tapyatāpakayorbhede
analyzed: tat katham ekasmin advaye bhavitum arhataḥ iti arthaḥ  tat evam aupaniṣadam matam asamañjasam uktvā sāṃkhyaḥ sva pakṣe tapya tāpakayoḥ bhede
translated: How, then, can they be in one, which is non-dual?

analyzed: mokṣam upapādayati jāti antara bhāve tu iti  dṛś darśana śaktyoḥ kila saṃyogaḥ tāpa nidānam
translated: Thus, having stated that the doctrine of the Upaniṣads is incoherent, the Sāṃkhya establishes liberation in his own doctrine, in the case of the difference between the object to be heated and the object that heats,🔽by saying, “But if they are of different species.”🔽The contact of the seer and the power of seeing is indeed the cause of heating.

analyzed: tasya hetuḥ aviveka darśana saṃskāraḥ vidyā
translated: The cause of that is the impression of the non-discriminating view, which is ignorance.

analyzed: sā ca viveka khyātyā vidyayā virodhi tvāt vinivartyate
translated: And that is removed by the knowledge of discrimination, which is knowledge, because it is opposed to it.

analyzed: tad nivṛttau tad hetukaḥ saṃyogaḥ nivartate
translated: When that is removed, the contact, which is caused by that, is removed.

analyzed: tad nivṛttau ca tad kāryaḥ tāpaḥ nivartate
translated: And when that is removed, the heating, which is its effect, is removed.

analyzed: tat uktam pañcaśikha ācāryeṇa tad saṃyoga hetu vivarjanāt syāt ayam ātyantikaḥ duḥkha pratīkāraḥ iti
translated: That has been stated by the teacher Pañcaśikha: “By avoiding the cause of that contact, this absolute remedy for pain would be.”

analyzed: atra ca na sākṣāt puruṣasya apariṇāminaḥ bandha mokṣau
translated: And here, bondage and liberation are not directly of the unchanging Self.

analyzed: kintu buddhi sattvasya eva citi chāyā āpattyā labdha caitanyasya
translated: But rather of the intellect-stuff, which has attained sentience by the reflection of consciousness.

analyzed: tathā hi  iṣṭa aniṣṭa guṇa svarūpa avadhāraṇam avibhāga āpannam asya bhogaḥ
translated: For thus:🔽The determination of the nature of desirable and undesirable qualities, not yet merged, is its experience.

analyzed: bhoktṛ svarūpa avadhāraṇam apavargaḥ
translated: The determination of the nature of the experiencer is liberation.

analyzed: tena hi buddhi satvam eva apavṛjyate
translated: Therefore, it is the intellect-stuff alone that is liberated.

original: tathāpi yathā jayaḥ parājayo vā yodheṣu vartamānaḥ prādhānyātsvāminyapadiśyate /
analyzed: tathā api yathā jayaḥ parājayaḥ vā yodheṣu vartamānaḥ prādhānyāt svāmini apadiśyate
translated: Nevertheless, just as victory or defeat, occurring in the warriors, is attributed to the master by reason of his pre-eminence,

analyzed: evam bandha mokṣau buddhi satve vartamānau kathañcid puruṣe padiśyete
translated: so bondage and liberation, occurring in the intellect-stuff, are somehow attributed to the Self.

analyzed: sa hi avibhāga apatyā tad phalasya bhoktā iti
translated: For he is the enjoyer of its fruit by reason of non-separation.

analyzed: tat etat abhisaṃdhāya āha syāt api kadācid mokṣa upapattiḥ iti
translated: With this in view, he says: Liberation is possible for him also, somehow.

analyzed: atra ucyatena  eka tvāt eva tapya tāpaka bhāva anupapatteḥ
translated: To this we reply: No.🔽Because the relation of the heated and the heater is not possible on account of identity.

analyzed: yatas ekatve tapya tāpaka bhāvaḥ na upapadyate ekatvāt eva
translated: Because, in identity, the relation of the heated and the heater is not possible, on account of identity itself.

analyzed: tasmāt sāṃvyavahārika bheda āśrayaḥ tapya tāpaka bhāvaḥ smābhiḥ abhyupeyaḥ
translated: Therefore, we accept the relation of the heated and the heater to be based on conventional difference.

original: tāpo hi sāṃvyavahārika eva na pāramārthika ityasakṛdāveditam /🔽bhavedeṣa doṣo yadyekātmatāyāṃ tapyatāpakāvanyonyasya viṣayaviṣayibhāvaṃ pratipadyeyātāmityasmadabhyupagama iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: tāpaḥ hi sāṃvyavahārikaḥ eva na pāramārthikaḥ iti asakṛt āveditam  bhavet eṣa doṣaḥ yadi eka ātmatāyām tapya tāpakau anyonyasya viṣaya viṣayi bhāvam pratipadyeyātām iti asmad abhyupagamaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: For it has been repeatedly declared that the pain is only empirical, not real.🔽This objection would hold if we admitted that the experiencer and the thing experienced are identical. But we do not admit this.

original: sāṃkhyo 'pi hi bhedāśrayaṃ tapyatāpakabhāvaṃ bruvāṇo na puruṣasya tapikarmatāmākhyātumarhati /
analyzed: sāṃkhyaḥ u pi hi bheda āśrayam tapya tāpaka bhāvam bruvāṇaḥ na puruṣasya tapi karma tām ākhyātum arhati
translated: The Sāṃkhya also, while maintaining that the relation of the thing experienced and the experiencer is based on difference, cannot maintain that the soul is the thing experienced.

analyzed: tasya apariṇāmi tayā tapi kriyā janita phala śāli tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because, being unmodifiable, it cannot be the receptacle of the result produced by the act of experiencing.

analyzed: kevalam anena sattvam tapyam
translated: The Sattva alone is the thing experienced.

analyzed: abhyupeyam tāpakam ca rajaḥ
translated: And the Rajas is to be admitted as the experiencer.

original: darśitaviṣayattvāttu buddhisatve tapye tadavibhāgāpatyā puruṣo 'pyanutapyata iva na tu tapyate 'pariṇāmitvādityuktaṃ /
analyzed: darśita viṣaya ttvāt tu buddhi satve tapye tad avibhāga āpatyā puruṣaḥ api anutapyate iva na tu tapyate pariṇāmi tvāt iti uktam
translated: But the soul, though unmodifiable, appears as if it were experienced, because the intellect, the Sattva, which is the thing experienced, is not distinguished from the soul. But it is not really experienced.

analyzed: tad avibhāga āpattiḥ ca avidyā
translated: And the non-distinction of the soul from the intellect is ignorance.

analyzed: tathā ca avidyā kṛtaḥ tapya tāpaka bhāvaḥ tvayā abhyupeyaḥ
translated: And thus the relation of the thing experienced and the experiencer, produced by ignorance, is to be admitted by you.

analyzed: saḥ yam asmābhiḥ ucyamānaḥ kim iti bhavataḥ puruṣaḥ iva ābhāti
translated: Why does this relation, which is being stated by us, appear to you as if it were the soul?

analyzed: api ca nitya tva abhyupagamāt ca tāpakasya anirmokṣa prasaṅgaḥ  śaṅkate tapya tāpaka śaktyoḥ nitya tve pi iti
translated: Moreover, because of the acceptance of eternality, there is the undesirable consequence of the impossibility of liberation.

original: sahādarśanena nimittena vartata iti sanimittaḥ saṃyogastadapekṣatvāditi /
analyzed: saha a darśanena nimittena vartate iti sa nimittaḥ saṃyogaḥ tad apekṣa tvāt iti
translated: He raises the doubt: Even if the power to be heated and the power to heat are eternal, the contact of the soul with the internal organ is occasional, because it is dependent on the presence of the cause of contact, which is the absence of mutual separation.

analyzed: nirākaroti na  a darśanasya tamasaḥ iti
translated: He refutes: No.🔽Because the absence of mutual separation is not a cause.🔽The absence of mutual separation is not a cause of contact.

analyzed: na tāvat puruṣasya taptiḥ iti uktam  kevalam iyam buddhi sattvasya tāpaka rajaḥ janitā
translated: It is not the case that the soul is heated, as stated earlier.🔽This is merely the heat generated by the contact of the heated internal organ with the soul.

original: tasya ca buddhisatvasya tāmasaviparyāsādātmanaḥ puruṣādbhedamapaśyataḥ puruṣastapyata ityabhimānaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca buddhi satvasya tāmasa viparyāsāt ātmanaḥ puruṣāt bhedam apaśyataḥ puruṣaḥ tapyate iti abhimānaḥ
translated: And that internal organ, due to the tamas-born error, not seeing the difference of the soul from the purusha, has the conceit that the purusha is heated.

analyzed: na tu puruṣaḥ viparyāsa tuṣeṇa api yujyate
translated: But the purusha is not even connected with the husk of error.

original: tasya tu buddhisatvasya sāttvikyā vivekakhyātyā tāmasīyamavivekakhyātirnivartanīyā /
analyzed: tasya tu buddhi satvasya sāttvikyā viveka khyātyā tāmasī iyam aviveka khyātiḥ nivartanīyā
translated: But that internal organ's tamas-born error of non-discrimination is to be removed by the sattva-born discrimination.

analyzed: na ca tamasi mūle śakyā atyantam ucchettum
translated: And that root of tamas cannot be completely cut off.

original: tathā vicchinnāpi chinnabadarīva punastamasodbhūtena sattvamabhibhūya vivekakhyātimapodya śataśikharāvidyāvirbhāvyeteti bateyamapavargakathā
analyzed: tathā vicchinnā api chinna badarī iva punar tamasā udbhūtena sattvam abhibhūya viveka khyātim apodya śata śikharā avidyā āvirbhāvyeta iti bata iyam apavarga kathā
translated: Thus, even though cut off, like a cut jujube tree, it arises again from the tamas that has arisen, overwhelms the sattva, removes the discrimination, and manifests the ignorance with a hundred peaks. Oh, this is the story of final liberation!

analyzed: tapasvinaḥ datta jala añjaliḥ prasajyeta
translated: If the soul were different from the body, then the soul, having given the water-oblation to the dead body, would be affected by grief.

analyzed: asmad pakṣe tu adoṣaḥ iti āha aupaniṣadasya tu iti
translated: But in our view, there is no fault. He says: But for one who is a knower of Brahman,

analyzed: yathā hi mukham avadātam api malina ādarśa tala upādhi kalpita pratibimba bhedam malina tām upaiti
translated: Just as a face, though fair, becomes soiled due to the difference in the reflected image superimposed by the surface of a dirty mirror,

analyzed: na ca tat vastutas malinam
translated: and that face is not really soiled,

analyzed: na ca bimbāt pratibimbam vastutaḥ bhidyate
translated: and the reflected image is not really different from the original object,

original: atha tasmin pratibimbe malinādarśopadhānānmalinatā padaṃ labhate /
analyzed: atha tasmin pratibimbe malina ādarśa upadhānāt malina tā padam labhate
translated: and when the soiling is removed from that reflected image,

original: tathā cātmano malinaṃ mukhaṃ paśyan devadattastapyate /
analyzed: tathā ca ātmanaḥ malinam mukham paśyan devadattaḥ tapyate
translated: and Devadatta, seeing his own soiled face, is distressed,

original: yadā tūpādhyapanayādbimbameva kalpanāvaśāt pratibimbaṃ taccāvadātamiti tattvamavagacchati tadāsya tāpaḥ praśāmyati naca malinaṃ me mukhamiti
analyzed: yadā tu upādhi apanayāt bimbam eva kalpanā vaśāt pratibimbam tat ca avadātam iti tattvam avagacchati tadā asya tāpaḥ praśāmyati na ca malinam me mukham iti
translated: but when he removes the superimposition and understands by the power of imagination that the original object itself is the reflected image and that is fair, then his distress is pacified and he does not think 'my face is soiled',

original: evamavidyopadhānakalpitāvacchedo jīvaḥ paramātmapratibimbakalpaḥ kalpitaireva śabdādibhiḥ saṃparkāttapyate natu tattvataḥ paramātmano 'sti
analyzed: evam avidyā upadhāna kalpita avacchedaḥ jīvaḥ paramātma pratibimba kalpaḥ kalpitaiḥ eva śabda ādibhiḥ saṃparkāt tapyate na tu tattvataḥ paramātmanoḥ sti
translated: in the same way, the individual soul, limited by the superimposition of ignorance, which is like a reflected image of the supreme self, is distressed by contact with sound etc. which are superimposed, but not really, for the supreme self

analyzed: yadā tu tat tvam asi iti vākya śravaṇa manana dhyāna abhyāsa paripāka prakarṣa paryanta jaḥ
translated: But when the intuition of the Self arises, born of the culmination of the practice of hearing, reflecting, and meditating on the sentence That thou art,

analyzed: sya sākṣātkāraḥ upajāyate tadā jīvaḥ śuddha buddha tattva svabhāvam ātmanaḥ nubhavan
translated: then the individual soul, experiencing the nature of the Self as pure consciousness,

analyzed: nirmṛṣṭa nikhila sa vāsana kleśa jālaḥ kevalaḥ svasthaḥ bhavati na
translated: becomes solitary and at ease, with the net of afflictions and their latent impressions completely removed.

original: cāsya punaḥ saṃsārabhayamasti taddhetoravāstavatvena samūlakāṣaṃ kaṣitatvāt /
analyzed: ca asya punar saṃsāra bhayam asti tad hetoḥ avāstava tvena sa mūla kāṣam kaṣita tvāt
translated: And for him there is no more fear of worldly existence, because the cause of that has been uprooted along with its root by realizing its unreality.

analyzed: sāṃkhyasya tu sataḥ tamasaḥ śakya samuccheda tvāt iti
translated: But for the Sāṃkhya, the darkness [of ignorance] is incapable of being destroyed.

analyzed: tat idam uktam vikāra bhedasya ca vācā ārambhaṇa mātra tva śravaṇāt iti
translated: This is what is said: And because the difference of modifications is heard to be mere verbal designation.

analyzed: pradhāna kāraṇa vādaḥ iti
translated: The doctrine of primordial matter as the cause.

original: yathaiva pradhānakāraṇavādo brahmakāraṇavādavirodhyevaṃ paramāṇukāraṇavādo 'pyataḥ so 'pi nirākartavyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā eva pradhāna kāraṇa vādaḥ brahma kāraṇa vāda virodhī evam paramāṇu kāraṇa vādaḥ api atas saḥ pi nirākartavyaḥ
translated: Just as the doctrine of primordial matter as the cause is opposed to the doctrine of Brahman as the cause, so is the doctrine of atoms as the cause. Therefore that [doctrine of atoms] should also be refuted.

original: 'etena śiṣṭāparigrahā api vyākhyātāḥ'ityasya prapañca ārabhyatetatra vaiśeṣikā brahmakāraṇatvaṃ dūṣayāṃbabhūvuḥ /
analyzed: etena śiṣṭa aparigrahāḥ api vyākhyātāḥ iti asya prapañcaḥ ārabhyate tatra vaiśeṣikāḥ brahma kāraṇatvam dūṣayāṃbabhūvuḥ
translated: By this, the doctrines of other schools that are not accepted by the learned are also explained. The elaboration of this [verse] begins. There, the Vaiśeṣikas criticized the doctrine of Brahman as the cause.

analyzed: cetanam ced ākāśa ādīnām upādānam tad ārabdham ākāśa ādi cetanam syāt
translated: If space, etc., have a conscious substance as their material cause, then space, etc., which are produced from that [conscious substance], would be conscious.

analyzed: kāraṇa guṇa krameṇa hi kārye guṇa ārambhaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: For it is seen that the qualities of the effect arise in accordance with the qualities of the cause.

analyzed: yathā śuklaiḥ tantubhiḥ ārabdhaḥ paṭaḥ śuklaḥ
translated: Just as a cloth woven from white threads is white.

analyzed: na jātu asau kṛṣṇaḥ bhavati
translated: It is never black.

analyzed: evam cetanena ārabdham ākāśa ādi cetanam bhavet na tu acetanam
translated: In the same way, space, etc., produced by a conscious [substance], would be conscious, not unconscious.

analyzed: tasmāt acetana upādānam eva jagat
translated: Therefore, the world has only an unconscious material cause.

analyzed: tat ca acetanam paramāṇavaḥ
translated: And that unconscious [material cause] is atoms.

analyzed: sūkṣmāt khalu sthūlasya utpattiḥ dṛśyate
translated: For the gross is seen to arise from the subtle.

analyzed: yathā tantubhiḥ paṭasya evam aṃśubhyaḥ tantūnām evam apakarṣa paryantam kāraṇa dravyam ati sūkṣmam anavayavam avatiṣṭhate
translated: Just as a cloth from threads, so threads from yarns, and so on until the ultimate subtle cause, an indivisible substance, is reached.

analyzed: tat ca paramāṇu
translated: And that is an atom.

original: tasya tu sāvayavatve 'bhyupagamyamāne 'nantāvayavatvena sumerurājasarṣapayoḥ samānaparimāṇatvaprasaṅga ityuktam /
analyzed: tasya tu sāvayava tve bhyupagamyamāne nanta avayava tvena sumeru rājasarṣapayoḥ samāna parimāṇa tva prasaṅgaḥ iti uktam
translated: But if it is accepted that that [atom] has parts, it is said that the size of Mount Meru and a mustard seed would be the same, because of their infinite number of parts.

analyzed: tatra ca prathamam tāvat adṛṣṭa vat kṣetrajña saṃyogāt paramāṇau karma
translated: And there, first of all, an atom has action due to the conjunction of the unseen [potency] and the individual soul.

analyzed: paramāṇu antareṇa saṃyujya dvyaṇukam ārabhate
translated: Then it joins with another atom and produces a dyad.

original: bahavastu paramāṇavaḥ saṃyuktā na sahasā sthūlamārabhante /
analyzed: bahavaḥ tu paramāṇavaḥ saṃyuktāḥ na sahasā sthūlam ārabhante

original: tāmimāṃ śaṅkāṃ sūddhārāmāhaparamāṇūnāṃ kalpitā iti /🔽nahyasti saṃbhavo niravayava ekastadaiva tenaiva saṃyuktaścāsaṃyuktaśceti /
analyzed: tām imām śaṅkām sūddhārām āha paramāṇūnām kalpitāḥ iti  na hi asti saṃbhavaḥ niravayavaḥ ekaḥ tadā eva tena eva saṃyuktaḥ ca a saṃyuktaḥ ca iti
translated: He answers this doubt, saying the conjunction of atoms is imagined.🔽For it is not possible that an indivisible one is both conjoined and not conjoined with itself at the same time.

analyzed: bhāva abhāvayoḥ ekasmin advaye virodhāt
translated: Because existence and non-existence are contradictory in one non-dual thing.

analyzed: avirodhe vā na kvacid api virodhaḥ vakāśam āsādayeta
translated: Or if there is no contradiction, then contradiction would not find an opportunity anywhere.

analyzed: pratītiḥ tu pradeśa kalpanayā api kalpyate
translated: But the cognition is imagined even by the postulation of a part.

analyzed: tat idam uktam kalpitāḥ pradeśāḥ iti
translated: This is what is said: The parts are imagined.

analyzed: tathā ca sūddhārā iyam iti tām uddharati kalpitānām avastu tvāt iti
translated: And thus this is to be extracted. He extracts it: because imagined things are unreal.

analyzed: tṛtīyām vyākhyām āha yathā ca ādisarge iti
translated: He states the third explanation: And just as at the beginning of creation.

original: nanvabhighātanodanādayaḥ pralayārambhasamaye kasmādvibhāgārambhakakarmahetavo na saṃbhavantyata āhanahi tatrāpi kiñcinniyatamiti /
analyzed: nanu abhighāta nodana ādayaḥ pralaya ārambha samaye kasmāt vibhāga ārambhaka karma hetavaḥ na saṃbhavanti atas āha nahi tatra api kiñcid niyatam iti
translated: But why are collisions, impulsions, etc., not the causes of the actions that begin the division at the time of dissolution? To this he says: For there also nothing is fixed.

analyzed: saṃbhavanti abhighāta ādayaḥ kadācid kvacid
translated: Collisions, etc., may occur somewhere at some time.

analyzed: na tu aparyāyeṇa sarvasmin
translated: But not by turns in everything.

analyzed: niyama hetoḥ abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no cause for restriction.

analyzed: na pralaya prasiddhi artham iti
translated: Not for the sake of establishing dissolution.

original: yadyapi śarīrādipralayārambhe 'sti duḥkhabhogastathāpyasau pṛthivyādipralaye nāstītyabhipretyedamuditamiti mantavyam ////🔽START / / /
analyzed: yadi api śarīra ādi pralaya ārambhe sti duḥkha bhogaḥ tathā api asau pṛthivī ādi pralaye na asti iti abhipretya idam uditam iti mantavyam  start
translated: Although there is the experience of suffering at the beginning of the dissolution of the body, etc., still it is to be understood that this is stated with the intention that it does not exist at the dissolution of earth, etc.

analyzed: samavāya abhyupagamāt ca sāmyāt anavasthiteḥ
translated: And because of the acceptance of inherence, there is infinite regress due to similarity.

analyzed: vyācaṣṭe samavāya abhyupagamāt ca iti
translated: He explains: And because of the acceptance of inherence.

original: na tāvat svatantraḥ samavāyo 'tyantaṃ bhinnaḥ samavāyibhyāṃ samavāyinau ghaṭayitumarhatyatiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: na tāvat svatantraḥ samavāyaḥ u tyantam bhinnaḥ samavāyibhyām samavāyinau ghaṭayitum arhati atiprasaṅgāt
translated: First, inherence cannot be independent, because it is absolutely different from the inherents, and cannot connect the inherents, as that would lead to an absurdity.

original: tasmādanena samavāyisaṃbandhinā satā samavāyinau ghaṭanīyau /🔽tathā ca samavāyasya saṃbandhāntareṇa samavāyisaṃbandhe 'bhyupagamyamāne 'navasthā /
analyzed: tasmāt anena samavāyi saṃbandhinā satā samavāyinau ghaṭanīyau  tathā ca samavāyasya saṃbandha antareṇa samavāyi saṃbandhe bhyupagamyamāne navasthā
translated: Therefore, it must be that which exists as related to the inherents that connects the inherents.🔽And if inherence is accepted as related by another relation, there would be an infinite regress.

original: athāsau saṃbandhibhyāṃ saṃbandhe na saṃbandhāntaramapekṣate saṃbandhisaṃbandhanaparamārthatvāt /🔽tathāhināsau bhinne 'pi saṃbandhinirapekṣo nirūpyate /
analyzed: atha asau saṃbandhibhyām saṃbandhe na saṃbandha antaram apekṣate saṃbandhi saṃbandhana parama artha tvāt  tathā hi nā asau bhinne saṃbandhi nirapekṣaḥ nirūpyate
translated: But if it does not require another relation in its relation with the relata, because its ultimate nature is to relate the relata,🔽it is not conceived even when the relata are different, without depending on them.

original: na ca tasmin sati samabanghināvasaṃbanghinau bhavataḥ /
analyzed: na ca tasmin sati samabanghinau asaṃbanghinau bhavataḥ
translated: And when it exists, the relata do not become unrelated.

original: tasmāt svabhāvādeva samavāyaḥ samavāyinorna saṃbandhāntareṇeti🔽nānavastheti codayatinanvihapratyayagrāhyā iti /
analyzed: tasmāt svabhāvāt eva samavāyaḥ samavāyinoḥ na saṃbandha antareṇa iti  na anavasthā iti codayati nanu iha pratyaya grāhyāḥ iti
translated: Therefore, inherence is by its very nature in the inherents, not by another relation.🔽Thus there is no infinite regress. This is objected to by saying But they are grasped by the cognition of inherence.

analyzed: pariharati na iti ucyate  saṃyogaḥ pi evam iti
translated: The answer is No, it is said.🔽Conjunction is also like this.

analyzed: tathā hi saṃyogaḥ pi saṃbandhi saṃbandhana parama arthaḥ
translated: For, conjunction also has the ultimate nature of relating the relata.

analyzed: na ca saṃyogibhyām vinā nirūpyate
translated: And even if it were different, it is not conceived apart from the conjoined things.

original: naca tasmin sati saṃyogināvasaṃyoginau bhavata iti tulyacarcaḥ /
analyzed: na ca tasmin sati saṃyoginau asaṃyoginau bhavataḥ iti tulya carcaḥ
translated: And when it exists, the conjoined things do not become unconjoined. Thus the argument is the same.

analyzed: yadi ucyeta guṇaḥ saṃyogaḥ
translated: If it is said that conjunction is a quality,

analyzed: na ca dravya asamavetaḥ guṇaḥ bhavati
translated: and a quality does not inhere in a substance,

analyzed: na ca asya samavāyam vinā samaveta tvam
translated: and it does not inhere without inherence,

analyzed: tasmāt saṃyogasya asti samavāyaḥ iti śaṅkām apākaroti na ca guṇa tvāt iti
translated: therefore conjunction has inherence, to remove this doubt he says and not because it is a quality.

original: yadyasamavāye 'syāguṇatvaṃ bhavati kāmaṃ bhavatu na naḥ kācitkṣatiḥ /
analyzed: yadi asamavāye syā guṇa tvam bhavati kāmam bhavatu na naḥ kācid kṣatiḥ
translated: If it is a fault for it to be a quality when there is no inherence, let it be so, we have no loss at all.

analyzed: tat idam uktam guṇa paribhāṣāyāḥ ca iti
translated: This is what is said: And because of the definition of a quality.

analyzed: paramārthataḥ tu dravya āśrayi iti uktam
translated: But in reality it is said to inhere in a substance.

original: tacca vināpi samavāyaṃ svarūpataḥ saṃyogasyopapadyata eva /
analyzed: tat ca vinā api samavāyam svarūpataḥ saṃyogasya upapadyate eva
translated: And that is possible for conjunction even without inherence, by its own nature.

translated: And it is not proper to say that conjunction is inhering because it requires an inhering and non-inhering cause due to being an effect.

analyzed: aja saṃyogasya atathātva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the undesirable consequence that the conjunction of the unborn would not be so.

original: api ca samavāyasyāpi saṃbandhyadhīnasadbhāvasya saṃbandhinaścaikasya dvayorvā vināśitvena vināśitvātkāryatvam /

translated: Moreover, inherence also has the nature of being an effect, because it exists dependent on the relata and the relata are either one or two, and because of the nature of being destroyed.

original: nahyasti saṃbhavo guṇo vā guṇaguṇinau vāvayavo vāvayavāvayavinau vā na sto 'pyasti ca tayoḥ saṃbandha iti /

translated: For it is not possible that a quality or the qualified, or a part or the whole, do not exist, yet their relation exists.

analyzed: tasmāt kāryaḥ samavāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, inherence is an effect.

original: tathā ca yathaiṣa nimittakāraṇamātrādhīnotpāda evaṃ saṃyogo 'pi /
