translated: But the material cause has the nature of the universal.

original: evaṃ vyavasthite yathā suvarṇadravyaṃ kāṭhinyāvasthāmapahāya dravāvasthayā pariṇataṃ /
analyzed: evam vyavasthite yathā suvarṇa dravyam kāṭhinya avasthām apahāya drava avasthayā pariṇatam
translated: When this is the case, just as a gold substance, having abandoned the state of solidity, transforms into the liquid state,

original: na ca tatrāvayavavibhāgaḥ sannapi dravatve kāraṇaṃ /
analyzed: na ca tatra avayava vibhāgaḥ san api drava tve kāraṇam
translated: and the division of parts, even though present there, is not the cause of liquidity,

analyzed: paramāṇūnām bhavat mate tad abhāvena drava tva anupapatteḥ
translated: because according to your view, the atoms would not have that [division of parts], and liquidity would not be possible.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā paramāṇu dravyam agni saṃyogāt kāṭhinyam apahāya drava tvena pariṇamate
translated: Therefore, just as an atomic substance, by contact with fire, abandons solidity and transforms into liquidity,

analyzed: na ca kāṭhinya drava tve parimāṇoḥ adhiricyete
translated: And hardness and fluidity are not dependent on dimension.

original: evaṃ mṛdvā suvarṇaṃ vā sāmānyaṃ piṇḍivasthāmapahāya kulālahemakārādi vyāpārādghaṭarucakīdyavasthāmāpadyate /🔽na tvavayavavināśāttatsaṃyogavināśādvā vinaṣṭumarhanti ghaṭarucakādayaḥ /
analyzed: evam mṛdvā suvarṇam vā sāmānyam piṇḍi vasthām apahāya kulāla hemakāra ādi vyāpārāt ghaṭa rucakī idya vasthām āpadyate  na tu avayava vināśāt tad saṃyoga vināśāt vā vinaṣṭum arhanti ghaṭa rucaka ādayaḥ
translated: Similarly, clay or gold, abandoning the state of a lump, assumes the state of a pot or ornament due to the operation of a potter or goldsmith.🔽But pots, ornaments, etc. cannot be destroyed by the destruction of their parts or the destruction of their conjunctions.

analyzed: nahi kapāla ādayaḥ tad saṃyogaḥ vā asamavāyi kāraṇam api tu
translated: For the potsherds, etc. are not its material cause, nor is the conjunction of those its non-inherent cause.

analyzed: sāmānyam upādānam
translated: But the universal is the material cause.

analyzed: tat ca nityam
translated: And that is eternal.

analyzed: na ca tad saṃyoga sacivam eka tvāt
translated: And it is not accompanied by conjunction, because it is one.

analyzed: saṃyogasya dviṣṭha tvena ekasmin abhāvāt
translated: Because conjunction is twofold, it does not exist in one.

original: tasmātsāmānyasya paramārthasato 'nirvācyā viśeṣāvasthāstadadhiṣṭhānā bhujaṅgādaya iva rajjvādyupādānāṃ upajanāpāyadharmāṇa iti sāṃpratam /
analyzed: tasmāt sāmānyasya paramārtha sataḥ nirvācyāḥ viśeṣa avasthāḥ tad adhiṣṭhānāḥ bhujaṅga ādayaḥ iva rajju ādi upādānām upajana apāya dharmāṇaḥ iti sāṃpratam
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that the states of the particular, which are inexpressible, are the substrata of the universal, like snakes, etc., which have the nature of arising and perishing, having clay, etc. as their material causes.

analyzed: prakṛtam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti  start  ubhayathā ca doṣāt
translated: He concludes the main point, therefore, etc.

original: anubhūyate hi pṛthivī gandharūparasasparśātmikā sthūlā /🔽āpo rasarūpasparśātmikāḥ sūkṣmāḥ /
analyzed: anubhūyate hi pṛthivī gandha rūpa rasa sparśa ātmikā sthūlā 🔽āpaḥ rasa rūpa sparśa ātmikāḥ sūkṣmāḥ
translated: Here is the Sanskrit-English alignment based on the Japanese translations:

analyzed: rūpa sparśa ātmakam tejaḥ sūkṣmataram
translated: Fire, consisting of form and touch, is subtler.

analyzed: sparśa ātmakaḥ vāyuḥ sūkṣmatamaḥ
translated: Air, consisting of touch, is subtlest.

analyzed: purāṇe pi smaryate
translated: It is also remembered in the Puranas:

analyzed: ākāśam śabda mātram tu sparśa mātram samāviśat
translated: Space is mere sound, but sound enters into mere touch.

analyzed: dviguṇaḥ tu tatas vāyuḥ śabda sparśa ātmakaḥ
translated: Air, twice as much, becomes sound and touch.

analyzed: rūpam tathā eva āviśataḥ śabda sparśa guṇau ubhau
translated: Form, in the same way, enters into both sound and touch.

original: triguṇastu tato vahniḥ sa śabdasparśavān bhavet ////
analyzed: triguṇaḥ tu tatas vahniḥ sa śabda sparśavān bhavet
translated: Fire, three times as much, becomes sound, touch, and form.

original: śabdaḥ sparśaśca rūpaṃ ca rasamātraṃ samāviśat /
analyzed: śabdaḥ sparśaḥ ca rūpam ca rasa mātram samāviśat
translated: Sound, touch, form, and taste enter into mere taste.

analyzed: tasmāt caturguṇāḥ āpaḥ vijñeyāḥ tu rasa ātmikāḥ
translated: Therefore, water should be known as four times as much, consisting of taste.

analyzed: śabdaḥ sparśaḥ ca rūpam ca rasaḥ ced gandham āviśat
translated: Sound, touch, form, taste, and smell enter into mere smell.

analyzed: saṃhatān gandha mātreṇa tān ācaṣṭe mahīm imām
translated: By mere smell, they are said to be combined and form this earth.

analyzed: tasmāt pañca guṇā bhūmiḥ sthūlā bhūteṣu dṛśyate
translated: Therefore, earth is seen to be five times as much in the gross elements.

original: śāntā ghorāśca mūḍhāśca viśeṣāstena te smṛtāḥ ////
analyzed: śāntāḥ ghorāḥ ca mūḍhāḥ ca viśeṣāḥ tena te smṛtāḥ
translated: Therefore, they are remembered as peaceful, terrible, and deluded.

analyzed: paraspara anupraveśāt dhārayanti parasparam
translated: By mutual penetration, they support each other.

analyzed: tena gandha ādayaḥ parasparam saṃhanyamānāḥ pṛthivī ādayaḥ
translated: Therefore, earth and the others, when combined with each other, are smell and so on.

original: tathā ca yathāyathā saṃhanyamānānāmupacayastathātathā saṃhatasya sthaulyaṃ /
analyzed: tathā ca yathā yathā saṃhanyamānānām upacayaḥ tathā tathā saṃhatasya sthaulyam
translated: And thus, as there is increase in the aggregation of atoms, so there is grossness in the aggregate.

analyzed: yathā yathā apacayaḥ tathā tathā saukṣmya tāratamyam
translated: As there is decrease, so there is subtlety in proportion.

analyzed: tat evam anubhava āgamābhyām avasthitam artham vaiśeṣikaiḥ an icchadbhiḥ api aśakya apahnavam āha gandha iti
translated: Thus, the Vaiśeṣikas, though unwilling to accept the established meaning by experience and scripture, say that it is impossible to deny, beginning with smell.

original: astu tāvacchabdo vaiśeṣikaistasya pṛthivyādiguṇatvenānabhyupagamāditi catvāri bhūtāni catustridvyekaguṇānyudāhṛtavān /
analyzed: astu tāvat śabdaḥ vaiśeṣikaiḥ tasya pṛthivī ādi guṇa tvena anabhyupagamāt iti catvāri bhūtāni catur tri dvi eka guṇāni udāhṛtavān
translated: Let it be so. The Vaiśeṣikas have cited the four elements as having four, three, two, and one quality, respectively, because they do not accept that sound is a quality of earth, etc.

analyzed: anubhava āgama siddham artham uktvā vikalpya dūṣayati tadvat
translated: Having stated the meaning established by experience and scripture, he criticizes it by raising objections: So too.

analyzed: sthūla pṛthivī ādi vat
translated: Like gross earth, etc.

analyzed: paramāṇavaḥ pi iti
translated: The atoms also.

analyzed: upacita guṇānām mūrti upacayāt
translated: Because there is increase in the qualities, there is increase in the form.

analyzed: upacita saṃhanyamānānām saṃghāta upacayāt
translated: Because there is increase in the aggregation of the accumulated, there is increase in the aggregate.

original: aparamāṇutvaprasaṅgaḥ sthūlatvāditi /🔽yastu brūte na gandhādisaṃghātaḥ paramāṇurapi tu gandhādyāśrayo dravyaṃ /
analyzed: aparamāṇu tva prasaṅgaḥ sthūla tvāt iti  yaḥ tu brūte na gandha ādi saṃghātaḥ paramāṇuḥ api tu gandha ādi āśrayaḥ dravyam
translated: There would be the consequence of non-atomicity due to grossness.🔽But one who says: The atom is not an aggregation of smell, etc., but a substance that is the substratum of smell, etc.

analyzed: na ca gandha ādīnām tad āśrayāṇām upacaye dravyasya upacayaḥ bhavitum arhati anya tvāt iti
translated: And even when there is increase in smell, etc., which are its substrata, the substance cannot reasonably have increase, because it is different.

analyzed: tam pratyāha na ca antareṇa api mūrti upacayam dravya sva rūpa upacayam iti arthaḥ
translated: In reply to that, he says: even without an increase in form, i.e., without an increase in the substance's own nature.

analyzed: kutas  kāryeṣu bhūteṣu guṇa upacaye mūrti upacaya darśanāt
translated: Why?🔽Because in effects, i.e., in the elements, an increase in qualities is seen to be an increase in form.

original: natāvat paramāṇavo rūpato gṛhyante kintu kāryadvārā /
analyzed: na tāvat paramāṇavaḥ rūpataḥ gṛhyante kintu kārya dvārā
translated: The atoms are not apprehended by form, but rather through the effect.

analyzed: kāryam ca na gandha ādibhyaḥ bhinnam
translated: And the effect is not different from smell etc.

original: yadā na tadādhāratayā gṛhyate 'pi tu tadātmakatayā /
analyzed: yadā na tad ādhāra tayā gṛhyate tu tad ātmaka tayā
translated: When it is not apprehended as the substratum of that, but rather as having that as its nature.

original: tathā ca teṣāmupacaye tadupacitaṃ dṛṣṭamiti paramāṇubhirapi tatkāraṇairevaṃ bhavitavyaṃ /
analyzed: tathā ca teṣām upacaye tat upacitam dṛṣṭam iti paramāṇubhiḥ api tad kāraṇaiḥ evam bhavitavyam
translated: And thus, when there is an increase in them, that increase is seen. Therefore, even the atoms, which are the cause of that, must be so.

analyzed: tathā ca aparamāṇu tvam sthūla tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, they are not atoms, because of being gross. This is the meaning.

analyzed: dvitīyam vikalpam dūṣayati akalpyamāne tu upacita apacita guṇa tve iti
translated: Refuting the second alternative, he says: But if the increase and decrease of qualities is not accepted...

analyzed: atha sarve caturguṇāḥ iti
translated: If it is said that all have four qualities...

analyzed: yadi api asmin kalpe sarveṣām sthaulya prasaṅgaḥ tathā api ati sphuṭa tayā upekṣya dūṣayati tatas psu api iti
translated: Even though in this assumption all would be gross, still, because it is very clear, it is ignored and refuted. Then in water also...

analyzed: vāyoḥ rūpavat tvena cākṣuṣa tva prasaṅgaḥ iti api draṣṭavyam  start
translated: It should also be seen that air would be visible because it has form...

analyzed: aparigrahāt ca atyantam anapekṣā
translated: And because they are not accepted, they are absolutely not depended upon.

analyzed: nigada vyākhyātena bhāṣyeṇa vyākhyātam
translated: The commentary has explained it by a literal explanation.

original: saṃpratyutsūtraṃ bhāṣyakṛdvaiśeṣikatantraṃ dūṣayatiapi ca vaiśeṣikā iti /
analyzed: saṃprati utsūtram bhāṣyakṛt vaiśeṣika tantram dūṣayati api ca vaiśeṣikāḥ iti
translated: Now, the author of the commentary, without referring to the sūtra, criticizes the Vaiśeṣika system: Moreover, the Vaiśeṣikas...
Dependence on substance means being defined in dependence on substance.

original: na hi yathā gavāśvamahiṣamātaṅgāḥ parasparānadhīnanirūpaṇāḥ svatantrā nirūpyante /
analyzed: na hi yathā gava aśva mahiṣa mātaṅgāḥ paraspara anadhīna nirūpaṇāḥ svatantrāḥ nirūpyante
translated: For just as cows, horses, buffaloes, and elephants are not mutually dependent for their definition, but are defined independently,

original: vanhyādyanadhīnotpattayo vā dhūmādayo yathā vanhyādyanadhīnanirūpaṇāḥ svatantrā nirūpyante /
analyzed: vanhi ādi anadhīna utpattayaḥ vā dhūma ādayaḥ yathā vanhi ādi anadhīna nirūpaṇāḥ svatantrāḥ nirūpyante
translated: or just as smoke and so on are not dependent on fire and so on for their origination, but are defined independently without being dependent on fire and so on,

analyzed: evam guṇa ādayaḥ na dravya ādi anadhīna nirūpaṇāḥ
translated: in the same way, qualities and so on are not defined independently of substance and so on.

original: api tu yadā yadā nirūpyante tadā tadā tadākāratayaiva prathante na tu prathāyāmeṣāmasti svātantryaṃ /
analyzed: api tu yadā yadā nirūpyante tadā tadā tad ākāra tayā eva prathante na tu prathāyām eṣām asti svātantryam
translated: But whenever they are defined, then at that time they manifest only in that form. There is no independence in their manifestation.

original: tasmānnātiricyante dravyādapi tu dravyameva sāmānyarūpaṃ tathā tathā prathata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt na atiricyante dravyāt api tu dravyam eva sāmānya rūpam tathā tathā prathate iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, they do not exceed substance. Rather, the meaning is that substance itself manifests in various ways in the form of universals and so on.

analyzed: dravya kārya tva mātram guṇa ādīnām dravya adhīna tvam iti manvānaḥ codayati nanu agneḥ anyasya api iti
translated: Thinking that the dependence of qualities and so on on substance is merely being the effect of substance, he raises the objection: But if something is other than fire...

analyzed: pariharati bheda pratīteḥ iti
translated: He replies: Because difference is cognized...

analyzed: na tad adhīna utpāda tām tad adhīna tvam ācakṣmahe kintu tad ākāra tām
translated: We do not say that the non-substantiality is dependent on the substance because it is produced from it, but rather because it has the same form as it.

analyzed: tathā ca na vyabhicāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus there is no fallacy, this is the meaning.

analyzed: śaṅkate guṇānām dravya adhīna tvam dravya guṇayoḥ ayuta siddha tvāt iti yadi ucyeta
translated: He doubts: If it is said that the dependence of qualities on substance is due to the non-simultaneity of substance and quality,

original: yatra hi dvāvākāriṇau vibhinnābhyāmākārābhyāmavagamyete tau saṃbaddhāsaṃbaddhau vā vaiyadhikaraṇyena pratibhāsete /
analyzed: yatra hi dvau ākāriṇau vibhinnābhyām ākārābhyām avagamyete tau saṃbaddha asaṃbaddhau vā vaiyadhikaraṇyena pratibhāsete
translated: where two things with forms are known by distinct forms, they appear as non-co-extensive, whether connected or not.

analyzed: yathā iha kuṇḍe dadhi
translated: As here, curd in the pot,

analyzed: yathā vā gauḥ aśvaḥ iti
translated: or as a cow and a horse.

analyzed: na tathā guṇa karma sāmānya viśeṣa samavāyāḥ
translated: Qualities, actions, universals, particulars and inherence are not like that.

analyzed: teṣām dravya kāra tayā ākāra antara ayogena dravyāt ākāriṇaḥ nya tvena ākāri tayā vyavasthāna abhāvāt sā iyam ayuta siddhiḥ
translated: For they are established as having a different form from substance, not as having a form, because they cannot have another form due to being the form of substance. This is non-simultaneity.

analyzed: tathā ca sāmānādhikaraṇyena prathā iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus they are manifested as co-extensive, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tām imām ayuta siddhim vikalpya dūṣayati tat punar ayuta siddha tvam iti
translated: He refutes this non-simultaneity by imagining it: But that non-simultaneity,

analyzed: tatra apṛthak deśa tvam tad abhyupagamena virudhyate iti āha apṛthak deśa tve iti
translated: there, the non-separateness of place is contradicted by accepting that. He says: In non-separateness of place,

original: yadi tu saṃyoginoḥ kāryayoḥ saṃbandhibhyāmanyadeśatve yutasiddhistato 'nyāyutasiddhiḥ /🔽nityayostu saṃyoginordvayoranyatarasya vā pṛthaggatimattvaṃ yutasiddhistato 'nyāyutasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: yadi tu saṃyoginoḥ kāryayoḥ saṃbandhibhyām anya deśa tve yuta siddhiḥ tatas  nityayoḥ tu saṃyoginoḥ dvayoḥ anyatarasya vā pṛthak gatimat tvam yuta siddhiḥ tatas
translated: If, however, the two conjoined things are in different places from the two relata, then they are yutasiddhi.🔽If the two eternal conjoined things or either of them moves separately, then they are yutasiddhi.

original: tathā cākāśaparamāṇvoḥ paramāṇvośca saṃyuktayoryutasiddhiḥ siddhā bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca ākāśa paramāṇvoḥ paramāṇvoḥ ca saṃyuktayoḥ yuta siddhiḥ siddhā bhavati
translated: Thus, the yutasiddhi of the conjoined space and atom, and of two atoms, is established.

original: guṇaguṇinośca śauklyapaṭayorayutasiddhiḥ siddhā bhavati /🔽nahi tatra śauklyapaṭābhyāṃ saṃbandhibhyāmanyadeśau śauklyapaṭau /
analyzed: guṇa guṇinoḥ ca śauklya paṭayoḥ ayuta siddhiḥ siddhā bhavati  nahi tatra śauklya paṭābhyām saṃbandhibhyām anya deśau śauklya paṭau
translated: And the ayutasiddhi of the quality and the substratum, of whiteness and cloth, is established.🔽For there are no cloth and whiteness in different places from the two relata.

analyzed: sati api paṭasya tad anya tantu deśa tve śauklyasya saṃbandhi paṭa deśa tvāt
translated: Even though the cloth is in the place of another thread, whiteness is in the place of the cloth, which is the relata.

analyzed: tat na
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: nityayoḥ ātma ākāśayoḥ aja saṃyoge ubhayasyāḥ api yuta siddheḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because in the conjunction of the eternal self and space with the non-eternal, both are not yutasiddhi.

analyzed: na hi tayoḥ pṛthak āśraya āśrita tvam anāśraya tvāt
translated: For they do not have a separate substratum and supported, because they are without a substratum.

analyzed: nā api dvayoḥ anyatarasya vā pṛthak gatimat tva mūrta tvena ubhayoḥ api niṣkriya tvāt
translated: Nor does either of the two move separately, because both are inactive due to being material.

analyzed: na ca aja saṃyogaḥ na asti tasya anumāna siddha tvāt
translated: And the conjunction with non-eternal is not non-existent, because it is established by inference.

analyzed: tathā hi ākāśam ātma saṃyogi
translated: For instance, Ākāśa is in contact with the Self;

analyzed: mūrta dravya saṅgi tvāt
translated: because it is in contact with corporeal substances;

original: ghaṭādivadityanumānam /🔽pṛthagāśrayāśrayitvapṛthaggatimattvalakṣaṇayutasiddheranyā tvayutasiddhiryadyapi nābhyupetavirodhamāvahati tathāpi na sāmānādhikaraṇyaprathāmupapādayitumarhati
analyzed: ghaṭa ādi vat iti anumānam  pṛthak āśraya āśrayi tva pṛthak gatimat tva lakṣaṇa yuta siddheḥ anyā tu ayuta siddhiḥ yadi api na abhyupeta virodham āvahati tathā api na sāmānādhikaraṇya prathām upapādayitum arhati
translated: like the Jar and other things—this is an Inference.🔽Though the ‘non-apprehension of what is apprehensible’ does not involve any contradiction of what is admitted, yet it cannot bring about the idea of co-ordination.

original: evaṃ lakṣaṇe 'pi hi samavāye guṇaguṇinorabhyupagamyamāne saṃbaddhe iti pratyayaḥ syānna tādātmyapratyayaḥ /
analyzed: evam lakṣaṇe hi samavāye guṇa guṇinoḥ abhyupagamyamāne saṃbaddhe iti pratyayaḥ syāt na tādātmya pratyayaḥ
translated: Even under the definition of ‘Inherence’ as ‘the relation of the inseparable, non-different, invariable, concomitance of things’, if the Inherence of the Quality and the Substance is admitted, then the notion that should appear should be that ‘the two are connected’, and not that ‘the two are non-different’;

analyzed: asya ca upapādanāya samavāyaḥ āsthīyate bhavadbhiḥ
translated: and it is for the bringing about of this notion that you postulate the ‘Inherence’ (of the Quality in the Substance).

original: sa cedāsthito 'pi na pratyayamimamupapādayet kṛtaṃ tatkalpanayā /
analyzed: sa ced āsthitaḥ na pratyayam imam upapādayet kṛtam tad kalpanayā
translated: If, even though postulated, it does not bring about the said notion, then there is no use in postulating it at all.

analyzed: na ca pratyakṣaḥ sāmānādhikaraṇya pratyayaḥ samavāya gocaraḥ
translated: Nor can the notion of co-ordination be regarded as perceptible, as pertaining to Inherence.

analyzed: tad viruddha artha tvāt  tad gocara tve
translated: Because it is contrary to that notion.🔽If it were pertaining to Inherence,

original: hi paṭe śukla ityevamākaraḥ syānna tu paṭaḥ śukla iti /
analyzed: hi paṭe śuklaḥ iti evam ākaraḥ syāt na tu paṭaḥ śuklaḥ iti
translated: then the expression should be ‘the cloth is white’, and not ‘the cloth is in the white’;

analyzed: na ca śukla padasya guṇa viśiṣṭa guṇi para tvāt evam prathā iti sāṃpratam
translated: and it cannot be right to argue that “the expression is as has been made because the word ‘white’ denotes the Substance as qualified by the Quality”;

analyzed: nahi śabda vṛtti anusāri pratyakṣam
translated: For perception does not follow the usage of words.

original: nahyagnirmāṇavaka ityupacaritāgnibhāvo māṇavakaḥ pratyakṣeṇa dahanātmanā prathate /
analyzed: na hi agniḥ māṇavakaḥ iti upacarita agni bhāvaḥ māṇavakaḥ pratyakṣeṇa dahana ātmanā prathate
translated: The boy, who is figuratively called fire because he is like fire, is not manifested by perception as having the nature of burning.

analyzed: na ca ayam abheda vibhramaḥ samavāya nibandhanaḥ bhinnayoḥ api iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that this is a delusion of non-difference based on inherence, even between different things.

original: guṇādisadbhāve tadbhede ca pratyakṣānubhavādanyasya pramāṇasyābhāvāttasya ca bhrāntatve sarvābhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: guṇa ādi sadbhāve tad bhede ca pratyakṣa anubhavāt anyasya pramāṇasya abhāvāt tasya ca bhrānta tve sarva abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because, in the case of the existence of qualities etc. and their difference, there is no means of knowledge other than perception and inference, and if that were deluded, it would lead to the absurdity of the non-existence of everything.

analyzed: tad āśrayasya tu bheda sādhanasya tad viruddha tayā utthāna asaṃbhavāt
translated: And because the basis for proving their difference, being contrary to that, cannot arise.

analyzed: tat idam uktam tasya tādātmyena eva pratīyamāna tvāt iti
translated: This is what is meant by saying because it is manifested as having that as its very nature.

analyzed: api ca ayuta siddha śabdo pṛthak utpattau mukhyaḥ
translated: Moreover, the word ayutasiddhi (inseparably connected) is primary in the sense of non-separate origination.

analyzed: sā ca bhavat mate na dravya guṇayoḥ asti
translated: And that does not exist for substance and quality according to your view.

analyzed: dravyasya prāk siddheḥ guṇasya ca paścāt utpatteḥ
translated: Because the substance exists before and the quality arises later.

analyzed: tasmāt mithyāvādaḥ yam iti āha yuta siddhayoḥ iti
translated: Therefore, this is a false statement. He says of what are inseparably connected.

analyzed: atha bhavatu kāraṇasya yuta siddhiḥ
translated: Now, let there be inseparable connection of the cause.

analyzed: kāryasya tu ayuta siddhi kāraṇa atirekeṇa abhāvāt iti āśaṅkya anyathā dūṣayati evam api iti
translated: The following objection might be urged: “As a matter of fact, the effect cannot be produced without the presence of the cause, hence the effect cannot be produced even when the Conjunction is there”. Anticipating this, the Author sets forth another objection against the Opponent’s view: [see verse 102 above]

original: saṃbandhidvayādhīnasadbhāvo hi saṃbandho nāsatyekasminnapi saṃbandhini bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: saṃbandhi dvaya adhīna sadbhāvaḥ hi saṃbandhaḥ na asati ekasmin api saṃbandhini bhavitum arhati
translated: A Relationship can subsist only when it is dependent upon both the relata; it cannot subsist when one of the relata is absent.

original: naca samavāyo nityaḥ svatantra iti coktamadhastāt /
analyzed: na ca samavāyaḥ nityaḥ svatantraḥ iti ca uktam adhastāt
translated: It has been explained before that Inherence is eternal and independent.

analyzed: na ca kāraṇa samavāyāt ananyā kāryasya utpattiḥ iti śakyam vaktum
translated: It cannot be right to say that the production of the Effect is nothing different from the Inherence of the Cause;

original: evaṃ hi sati samavāyasya nityatvābhyupagamāt kāraṇavaiyarthyaprasaṅgaḥ /🔽utpattau ca samavāyasya saiva kāryasyāstu kiṃ samavāyena /
analyzed: evam hi sati samavāyasya nitya tva abhyupagamāt kāraṇa vaiyarthya prasaṅgaḥ  utpattau ca samavāyasya sā eva kāryasya astu kim samavāyena
translated: because if it were so, then, as Inherence would be eternal, the Cause would become useless.🔽If the production of the Effect were due to Inherence, then, let that Inherence be the Effect itself; what would be the use of postulating the ‘Effect’?

analyzed: siddhayoḥ tu saṃbandhe yuta siddhi prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, the relationship of the two were already there, then the Conjunction would be there even before the production of the Effect.

analyzed: na ca anya ayuta siddhiḥ saṃbhavati iti etat uktam  tatas ca yat uktam vaiśeṣikaiḥ yuta siddhi abhāvāt
translated: And it has been already pointed out that there can be no Conjunction that is not ‘yutasiddhi’.

original: kāryakāraṇayoḥ saṃyogavibhāgau na vidyate itīdaṃ duruktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ saṃyoga vibhāgau na vidyate iti idam duruktam syāt
translated: In view of all this, what the Vaiśeṣika has said (under Text 16, above) regarding the Conjunction and Disjunction of Cause and Effect, to the effect that “Conjunction and Disjunction are not present in the Cause and Effect”, becomes a needless assertion;

analyzed: yuta siddhi abhāvasya eva abhāvāt
translated: because there can be no Conjunction that is not ‘yutasiddhi’.

analyzed: etena aprāpti saṃyogau yuta siddhiḥ iti api lakṣaṇam anupapannam
translated: For the same reason, the definition of ‘Non-apprehension’ (or ‘Negation’) as ‘the Conjunction of the non-apprehensible with Non-apprehension’ is also not right.

analyzed: mā bhūt aprāptiḥ kārya kāraṇayoḥ
translated: Let there not be non-contact between the effect and the cause.

analyzed: prāptiḥ tu anayoḥ saṃyogaḥ eva kasmāt na bhavati
translated: But why is their contact not itself the connection between them?

analyzed: tatra asyāḥ asaṃyoga tvāya anya ayuta siddhiḥ vaktavyā
translated: In that case, some other reason must be stated for why this is not a connection.

analyzed: tathā ca sā evā ucyatām kim anayā paraspara āśraya doṣa grastayā
translated: And let that very [reason] be stated. What is the use of this [view] that is afflicted with the fault of mutual dependence?

analyzed: na ca anyā saṃbhavati iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that no other [reason] is possible.

analyzed: yadi ucyeta aprāpti pūrvikā prāptiḥ anyatara karma jā ubhaya karma jā vā saṃyogaḥ
translated: If it is said that contact is preceded by non-contact, and is produced by the action of either one or both [of the two things that come into contact],

analyzed: yathā sthāṇu śyenayoḥ mallayoḥ vā
translated: like a post and a dog or two wrestlers,

analyzed: na ca tantu paṭayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ tathā
translated: and the relation between a thread and a cloth is not like that,

analyzed: utpanna mātrasya eva paṭasya tantu saṃbandhāt
translated: because as soon as the cloth is produced, it is related to the threads,

analyzed: tasmāt samavāyaḥ eva ayam iti atas āha yathā ca utpanna mātrasya iti
translated: therefore this [relation] is just inherence. To this he says: And as soon as it is produced...

original: saṃyogajo 'pi hi saṃyogo bhavadbhirabhyupeyate na kriyāja evetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: saṃyoga jaḥ pi hi saṃyogaḥ bhavadbhiḥ abhyupeyate na kriyā jaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: For you accept that contact is produced from contact, not only from action. This is the meaning.

analyzed: na ca aprāpti pūrvikā eva prāptiḥ saṃyogaḥ
translated: And contact is not just contact preceded by non-contact.

analyzed: ātma ākāśa saṃyoge nitye tad abhāvāt
translated: Because in the case of the contact of the self and space, which is eternal, that [non-contact] does not exist.

analyzed: kāryasya ca utpanna mātrasya ekasmin kṣaṇe kāraṇa prāpti virahāt ca iti
translated: And because as soon as the effect is produced, in one moment, there is an absence of contact with the cause.

original: api ca saṃbandhirūpātirikte saṃbandhe siddhe tadavāntarabhedāya lakṣaṇabhedo 'nuśrīyeta sa eva tu saṃbandhyatirikto 'siddhaḥ /
analyzed: api ca saṃbandhi rūpa atirikte saṃbandhe siddhe tad avāntarabhedāya lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ nuśrīyeta saḥ eva tu saṃbandhi atiriktaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Moreover, if a relation distinct from the forms of the relata were established, then a difference in definition could be inferred for its specific difference. But that very [relation] distinct from the relata is not established.

original: uktaṃ hi parastādatiriktaḥ saṃbandhibhyāṃ saṃbandho 'saṃbaddho na saṃbandhinau ghaṭayitumiṣṭe /
analyzed: uktam hi parastāt atiriktaḥ saṃbandhibhyām saṃbandhaḥ saṃbaddhaḥ na saṃbandhinau ghaṭayitum iṣṭe
translated: For it has been said later: A relation distinct from the relata, being unrelated, is not desired to connect the relata.

analyzed: saṃbandhi saṃbandhe ca anavasthitiḥ
translated: And in the relation of the relata, there is infinite regress.

analyzed: tasmāt upapatti anubhavābhyām na kāryasya kāraṇāt anya tvam
translated: Therefore, by reasoning and experience, the effect is not different from the cause.

analyzed: api tu kāraṇasya eva ayam anirvācyaḥ pariṇāma bhedaḥ iti
translated: But this is an indescribable transformation of the cause itself.

original: tasmāt kāryasya kāraṇādanatirekān kiṃ kena saṃbaddhaṃ /
analyzed: tasmāt kāryasya kāraṇāt anatirekān kim kena saṃbaddham
translated: Therefore, since the effect is not separate from the cause, what is related to what?

original: saṃyogasya ca saṃyogibhyāmanatirekāt kastayoḥ saṃyoga ityāhanāpi saṃyogasyeti /
analyzed: saṃyogasya ca saṃyogibhyām anatirekāt kaḥ tayoḥ saṃyogaḥ iti āha na api saṃyogasya iti
translated: And since conjunction is not separate from the conjoined, what is the conjunction of those two? He says: Nor is there a conjunction of conjunction.

analyzed: vicāra asaha tvena anirvācya tām asya a paribhāvayan āśaṅkate saṃbandhi śabda prati a vyatirekeṇa iti
translated: Not considering its indescribability due to inability to withstand scrutiny, he raises the doubt: Due to the exclusion of the words and concepts of the relata.

analyzed: nirākaroti na
translated: He refutes it.

analyzed: eka tve pi svarūpa bāhya rūpa apekṣayā iti
translated: Even in unity, due to the distinction between the intrinsic form and the external form.

analyzed: tad tad anirvacanīya aneka viśeṣa avasthā bheda apekṣayā ekasmin api nānā buddhi vyapadeśa upapattiḥ iti
translated: The various designations of a single thing are possible in relation to its various unutterable specific states.

analyzed: yathā ekaḥ devadattaḥ svagata viśeṣa apekṣayā manuṣyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: For example, Devadatta, being one, is called a man, a Brahmin, fair-complexioned, in relation to his own specific qualities.

analyzed: svagata avasthā bheda apekṣayā bālaḥ yuvā sthaviraḥ
translated: In relation to his own specific states, he is called a child, a youth, an old man.

analyzed: sva kriyā bheda apekṣayā śrotriyaḥ
translated: In relation to his own specific actions, he is called a scholar.

original: parāpekṣayā tu pitā putraḥ pautro bhrātā jāmāteti /🔽nidarśanāntaramāhayathā caikāpi satī rekheti /
analyzed: para apekṣayā tu pitā putraḥ pautraḥ bhrātā jāmātā iti  nidarśana antaram āha yathā ca ekā api satī rekhā iti
translated: But in relation to others, he is called a father, a son, a grandson, a brother, a son-in-law.🔽He gives another example: Just as a single line...

analyzed: dārṣṭāntike yojayati tathā saṃbandhinoḥ iti
translated: He applies it to the present case: So too, in relation to the connected...

analyzed: aṅgulyoḥ nairantaryam saṃyogaḥ
translated: The non-interruption of the fingers is conjunction.

analyzed: dadhi kuṇḍayoḥ auttarādharyam saṃyogaḥ
translated: The upper and lower positions of the curd and pot are conjunction.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ tu tādātmye pi anirvācyasya kāryasya bhedam vivakṣitvā asaṃbandhinoḥ iti uktam
translated: But in the case of cause and effect, even though there is identity, the word connected is used with the intention of indicating the difference of the unutterable effect.

analyzed: nā api saṃbandhi viṣaya tve saṃbandha śabda pratyayayoḥ
translated: Nor is the word and the concept of relation restricted to the relata.

analyzed: iti etat api anirvācya bheda abhiprāyam
translated: This too is said with the intention of an unutterable difference.

analyzed: api ca adṛṣṭa vat kṣetra saṃyogāt paramāṇu manasoḥ ca ādyam karma bhavadbhiḥ iṣyate
translated: Moreover, the initial action of atoms and mind is accepted by you as arising from the conjunction of the unseen and the field.

analyzed: agneḥ ūrdhva jvalanam vāyoḥ tiryak pavanam aṇu manasoḥ ca ādyam karma iti adṛṣṭa kāritāni iti vacanāt
translated: 🔽For it is said: 'The upward flame of fire, the sideways blowing of wind, and the first action of the subtle mind are due to unseen forces.'

analyzed: na ca aṇu manasoḥ ātmānā pradeśena saṃyogaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And the soul cannot be in contact with the atoms and the mind by its whole extent;

analyzed: saṃbhave ca aṇu manasoḥ ātma vyāpi tvāt parama mahā tvena an aṇu tva prasaṅgāt
translated: for if it could, the atoms and the mind would pervade the soul, and the soul would be of the nature of the highest magnitude, and not of the nature of an atom.

analyzed: na ca pradeśa vṛttiḥ anayoḥ ātmanā saṃyogaḥ pradeśa tvāt ātmanaḥ
translated: Nor can the soul be in contact with the atoms and the mind by a part of itself, because the soul is without parts.

analyzed: kalpanāyāḥ ca vastu tattva vyavasthāpana asaha tvāt atiprasaṅgāt iti āha tathā aṇu ātma manasām iti
translated: And the assumption of a contact of the soul with the atoms and the mind by a part of itself would lead to an absurdity, because the soul is without parts.

original: kiñcānyat dvābhyāmaṇubhyāṃ kāraṇābhyāṃ sāvayavasya kāryasyadvyaṇukasyākāśeneva saṃśleṣānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: kiñca anyat dvābhyām aṇubhyām kāraṇābhyām sa avayavasya kāryasya dvyaṇukasya ākāśena iva saṃśleṣa anupapattiḥ
translated: And further, the conjunction of the two atoms, which are the cause, with the effect, the dyad, which is composed of parts, cannot take place like that of the dyad with the ākāśa.

original: saṃśleṣaḥ saṃgraho yata ekasaṃbandhyākarṣe saṃbandhyantarākarṣo bhavati tasyānupapattiriti /
analyzed: saṃśleṣaḥ saṃgrahaḥ yatas eka saṃbandhi ākarṣe saṃbandhi antara ākarṣaḥ bhavati tasya anupapattiḥ iti
translated: Conjunction means the union of two things, so that by the attraction of one the other is attracted. This is impossible.

original: ata eva saṃyogādanyaḥkāryakāraṇadravyayorāśrayāśritabhāvo 'nyathā nopapadyata ityavaśyaṃ kalpanīyaḥ samavāya iti cet /
analyzed: atas eva saṃyogāt anyaḥ kārya kāraṇa dravyayoḥ āśraya āśrita bhāvaḥ nyathā na upapadyate iti avaśyam kalpanīyaḥ samavāyaḥ iti ced
translated: For the same reason the relation of the effect to the cause, which is different from conjunction, cannot be otherwise accounted for than by the assumption of inherence.

analyzed: nirākaroti na
translated: To this he says, No.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why not?

analyzed: itaretara āśraya tvāt
translated: Because of mutual dependence.

analyzed: tat vibhajate kārya kāraṇayoḥ hi iti
translated: He analyzes that with For cause and effect, etc.

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: Moreover, what else?

analyzed: paramāṇūnām iti
translated: Of atoms, etc.

analyzed: ye hi paricchinnāḥ te sa avayavāḥ
translated: For those that are limited are with parts,

analyzed: yathā ghaṭa ādayaḥ
translated: like pots, etc.

analyzed: tathā ca paramāṇavaḥ
translated: And atoms are like that.

analyzed: tasmāt sa avayavāḥ anityāḥ syuḥ
translated: Therefore, they would be with parts and impermanent.

analyzed: aparicchinna tve ca ākāśa ādi vat paramāṇu tva vyāghātaḥ śaṅkata iyān tvam iti
translated: And if they are not limited, there is the fear of contradicting atomhood, like space. He says you fear (v. 1).

analyzed: nirākaroti na
translated: He refutes (it) with No.

analyzed: sthūla iti
translated: Because of grossness, etc.

original: kiṃ sūkṣmatvāt paramāṇavo na vinaśyantyatha niravayavatayā tatra pūrvasmin kalpe idamuktamvastubhūtāpīti /
analyzed: kim sūkṣma tvāt paramāṇavaḥ na vinaśyanti atha niravayava tayā tatra pūrvasmin kalpe idam uktam vastu bhūtā api iti
translated: Are atoms not destroyed because of subtlety, or because of being partless? In the former case, this is said: Even though it is a real entity, etc.

analyzed: bhavat mate uttaram kalpam āśaṅkya nirākaroti vinaśyantaḥ pi avayava vibhāgena iti
translated: In the latter case, fearing that you would think that atoms are not destroyed because of being partless, he refutes that with Even though they are destroyed by the division of parts, etc.

original: yathā hi ghṛtasuvarṇādīnāmavibhajyamānāvayavānāmapīti /🔽yathā hi piṣṭapiṇḍo 'vinaśyadavayavasaṃyoga eva prathate /
analyzed: yathā hi ghṛta suvarṇa ādīnām a vibhajyamāna avayavānām api iti  yathā hi piṣṭa piṇḍaḥ vinaśyat avayava saṃyogaḥ eva prathate
translated: For example, of ghee, gold, etc., even though the parts are not divided, etc.🔽For example, even though the parts of a lump of flour are not destroyed, it spreads out.

analyzed: prathamānaḥ ca aśva śapha ākāra tām nīyamānaḥ puroḍāśa tām āpadyate
translated: And when spreading out, it is made into the shape of a horse's hoof and becomes a cake.

analyzed: tatra piṇḍaḥ naśyati puroḍāśaḥ ca utpadyate
translated: There, the lump is destroyed and the cake is produced.

analyzed: nahi tatra piṇḍa avayava saṃyogāḥ vinaśyanti
translated: For there the conjunctions of the parts of the lump do not perish.

original: api tu saṃyuktā eva santaḥ paraṃ prathanena nudyamānā adhikadeśavyāpakā bhavanti /
analyzed: api tu saṃyuktāḥ eva santaḥ param prathanena nudyamānāḥ adhika deśa vyāpakāḥ bhavanti
translated: But rather, remaining in conjunction, they are pushed out by expansion and become pervaders of a greater space.

original: evamagnisaṃyogena suvarṇadravyāvayavāḥ saṃyuktā eva santo dravībhāvamāpadyante /
analyzed: evam agni saṃyogena suvarṇa dravya avayavāḥ saṃyuktāḥ eva santaḥ dravībhāvam āpadyante
translated: In the same way, the parts of the gold substance, in conjunction with the contact with fire, attain fluidity.

analyzed: na tu mithas vibhajyante
translated: But they are not separated from each other.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā avayava saṃyoga vināśau antareṇa api suvarṇa piṇḍaḥ vinaśyati  saṃyoga antara utpādam antareṇa ca
translated: Therefore, just as the lump of gold perishes without the destruction of the conjunctions of the parts,

analyzed: suvarṇe dravaḥ upajāyate
translated: and fluidity arises in the gold without the production of another conjunction,

original: evamantareṇāpyavayavasaṃyogavināśaṃ paramāṇavo vinaṅkṣyantyanye cotpatsyanta iti sarvamavadātam ////🔽START / / /
analyzed: evam antareṇa api avayava saṃyoga vināśam paramāṇavaḥ vinaṅkṣyanti anye ca utpatsyante iti sarvam avadātam  start
translated: in the same way, the atoms will perish and others will be produced without the destruction of the conjunctions of the parts. Thus everything is clear.

analyzed: samudāyaḥ ubhaya hetuke tad aprāptiḥ 🔽avāntara saṃgatim āha 🔽vaiśeṣika rāddhānte iti 🔽vaiśeṣikāḥ khalu ardhavaināśikāḥ
translated: Here is the Sanskrit-English alignment based on the Japanese translations:

original: te hi paramāṇvākāśādikkālātmamanasāṃ ca sāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyānāṃ ca guṇānāṃ ca keṣāñcinnityatvamabhyupetya śeṣāṇāṃ niranvayavināśamupayanti /
analyzed: te hi paramāṇu ākāśa ādiś kāla ātma manasām ca sāmānya viśeṣa samavāyānām ca guṇānām ca keṣāñcid nitya tvam abhyupetya śeṣāṇām niranvaya vināśam upayanti
translated: For they, accepting the eternality of atoms, space, direction, time, self, mind, universals, particulars, inherence, and some qualities, maintain the absolute destruction of the rest.

analyzed: tena terdha vaināśikāḥ
translated: Therefore they are half-materialists.

original: tena tadupanyāso vaināśikatvasāmyena sarvavaināśikān smārayatīti tadanantaraṃ vaināśikamatanirākaraṇamiti /
analyzed: tena tad upanyāsaḥ vaināśika tva sāmyena sarva vaināśikān smārayati iti tad anantaram vaināśika mata nirākaraṇam iti
translated: Therefore, by similarity of materialism, the mention of them reminds us of all materialists, so the refutation of the materialist view comes next.

analyzed: ardhavaināśikānām sthirabhāvavādīnām samudāya ārambhaḥ upapadyeta api
translated: For the half-materialists who believe in enduring entities, the origination of the whole is possible.

analyzed: kṣaṇika bhāva vādīnām tu asau dūrāpetaḥ iti upapādayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: But for those who believe in momentary entities, it is far removed, as we will explain.

analyzed: iti uktam
translated: Therefore it is said all the more so.

original: tadidaṃ dūṣaṇāya vaināśikamatamupanyasituṃ tatprakārabhedānāhasa ca bahuprakāra iti /
analyzed: tat idam dūṣaṇāya vaināśika matam upanyasitum tad prakāra bhedān āha sa ca bahu prakāraḥ iti
translated: To refute this, in order to present the materialist view, he states its different types: And it is of many kinds.

analyzed: vādi vaicitryāt khalu
translated: Indeed, due to the diversity of proponents.

analyzed: kecid sarva astitvam eva rāddhāntam pratipadyante kecid jhāna mātra astitvam
translated: Some accept the conclusion that everything exists, some the existence of mere cognition.

analyzed: kecid sarva śūnyatām
translated: Some the complete emptiness of everything.

original: atha tvatrabhavatāṃ sarvajñānāṃ tattvapratipattibhedo na saṃbhavati /
analyzed: atha tu atrabhavatām sarvajñānām tattva pratipatti bhedaḥ na saṃbhavati
translated: But if there is no difference in the realization of reality among all the omniscient ones here,

analyzed: tattvasya aikarūpyāt iti etat a paritoṣeṇa āha vineya bhedāt vā
translated: To counter the dissatisfaction with the statement that it is due to the oneness of reality, he says: Or due to the difference in disciples.

analyzed: hīna madhyama utkṛṣṭa dhiyaḥ hi śiṣyāḥ bhavanti
translated: For disciples have inferior, middling, and superior intellects.

original: tatra ye hīnamatayaste sarvāstitvavādena tadāśayānurodhācchūnyatāyāmavatāryante /🔽ye tu madhyamāste jñānamātrāstitvena śūnyatāyāmavatāryante /

translated: It cannot be produced, because the production of an effect is pervaded by dependence on the observation of an intelligent being, and

translated: When that blazes in contact with the sense organs and objects, that set of causes becomes sufficient for the effect in such and such a way,🔽and illuminating in this way, controlling the non-intelligent causes, it brings about the effect.

analyzed: tatra aha citta abhijvalanasya ca samudāya sidydh adhīna tvāt

original: tatrāsya hetūpanibandho yadidamavidyāpratyayāḥ saṃskārā yāvajjātipratyayaṃ jarāmaraṇādīti avidyā cennābhaviṣyannaiva saṃskārā ajaniṣyanta /
analyzed: tatra asya hetu upanibandhaḥ yat idam avidyā pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ yāvajjāti pratyayam jarā maraṇa ādi iti avidyā ced na abhaviṣyat na eva saṃskārāḥ ajaniṣyanta
translated: If birth did not exist, old age and death would not arise.

analyzed: evam yāvajjātiḥ
translated: Thus, up to birth.

original: jātiścennābhaviṣyannaiva jarāmaraṇādaya utpatsyanta /🔽tatrāvidyāyā naivaṃ bhavatyahaṃ saṃskārānabhinirvartayāmīti /
analyzed: jātiḥ ced na abhaviṣyat na eva jarā maraṇa ādayaḥ utpatsyanta  tatra avidyāyāḥ na evam bhavati aham saṃskārān abhinirvartayāmi iti
translated: If birth did not exist, old age and death would not occur.🔽Among them, ignorance does not think, I bring about the formations.

original: saṃskārāṇāmapi naivaṃ bhavati vayamavidyayā nirvartitā iti /
analyzed: saṃskārāṇām api na evam bhavati vayam avidyayā nirvartitāḥ iti
translated: And the formations also do not think, We are brought about by ignorance.

original: evaṃ yāvajjātyā api naivaṃ bhavatyahaṃ jarāmaraṇādyabhinirvartayāmīti /
analyzed: evam yāvat jātyāḥ api na evam bhavati aham jarā maraṇa ādi abhinirvartayāmi iti
translated: In the same way, up to birth also does not think, I bring about old age, death, and so on.

original: jarāmaraṇādīnāmapi naivaṃ bhavati vayaṃ jātyādibhirnirvartitā iti /
analyzed: jarā maraṇa ādīnām api nā evam bhavati vayam jāti ādibhiḥ nirvartitāḥ iti
translated: And old age, death, and so on also do not think, We are brought about by birth and so on.

original: atha ca satsvavidyādiṣu svayamacetaneṣu cetanāntarānadhiṣṭhiteṣvapi saṃskārādīnāmutpattiḥ /
analyzed: atha ca satsu avidyā ādiṣu svayam acetaneṣu cetanā antara anadhiṣṭhiteṣu api saṃskāra ādīnām utpattiḥ
translated: Yet, when ignorance and so on exist, even though they are themselves insentient and not controlled by another sentience, the formations and so on arise.

original: bījādiṣviva satsvacetaneṣu cetanāntarānadhiṣṭhiteṣvapyaṅkurādīnām /🔽idaṃ pratītya prāpyedamutpadyata ityetāvanmātrasya dṛṣṭatvāccetanādhiṣṭhānasyānupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: bīja ādiṣu iva satsu acetaneṣu cetanā antara anadhiṣṭhiteṣu api aṅkura ādīnām  idam pratītya prāpya idam utpadyate iti etāvat mātrasya dṛṣṭa tvāt cetanā adhiṣṭhānasya anupalabdheḥ
translated: Just as, when seeds and so on exist, even though they are themselves insentient and not controlled by another sentience, sprouts and so on arise.🔽Because only this much is seen: This arises in dependence on that, this occurs due to the occurrence of that, and the control of sentience is not observed.

analyzed: saḥ yam ādhyātmikasya pratītyasamutpādasya hetu upanibandhaḥ
translated: This is the causal relation in internal dependent arising.

analyzed: atha pratyaya upanibandhaḥ pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa vijñāna dhātūnām samavāyāt bhavati kāyaḥ
translated: Now, the body arises from the combination of the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements.

original: tatra kāyasya pṛthivīdhātuḥ kāṭhinyaṃ nirvartayati /🔽abdhātuḥ snehayati kāyam /
analyzed: tatra kāyasya pṛthivī dhātuḥ kāṭhinyam nirvartayati  ap dhātuḥ snehayati kāyam
translated: Among them, the earth element in the body forms solidity.🔽The water element moistens the body.

original: tejodhātuḥ kāyasyāśitapīte paripācayati /🔽vāyudhātuḥ kāyasya śvāsādi karoti /
analyzed: tejaḥ dhātuḥ kāyasya aśita pīte paripācayati  vāyu dhātuḥ kāyasya śvāsa ādi karoti
translated: The fire element digests what is eaten and drunk in the body.🔽The wind element causes breathing, etc. in the body.

analyzed: ākāśa dhātuḥ kāyasya antar suṣira bhāvam karoti
translated: The space element makes the interior of the body hollow.

original: yastu nāmarūpāṅkuramabhinirvartayati pañcavijñānakāryasaṃyuktaṃ sāsravaṃ ca manovijñānaṃ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu nāma rūpa aṅkuram abhinirvartayati pañca vijñāna kārya saṃyuktam sa āsravam ca manaḥ vijñānam
translated: That which produces the sprout of name-and-form, along with the five sense consciousnesses, is defiled mental consciousness.

analyzed: saḥ yam ucyate vijñāna dhātuḥ
translated: This is called the consciousness element.

original: yadā hyādhyātmikāḥ pṛthivyādidhātavo bhavantyavikalāstadā sarveṣāṃ samavāyādbhavati kāyasyotpattiḥ /
analyzed: yadā hi ādhyātmikāḥ pṛthivī ādi dhātavaḥ bhavanti avikalāḥ tadā sarveṣām samavāyāt bhavati kāyasya utpattiḥ
translated: When the internal earth and other elements are present without deficiency, then the body arises from the combination of all of them.

original: tatra pṛthivyādidhātūnāṃ naivaṃ bhavati vayaṃ kāyasya kāṭhinyādi nirvartayāma iti /
analyzed: tatra pṛthivī ādi dhātūnām na evam bhavati vayam kāyasya kāṭhinya ādi nirvartayāmaḥ iti
translated: Among them, the earth and other elements do not think, We form the solidity, etc. of the body.

analyzed: kāyasya api nā evam bhavati jñānam aham ebhiḥ pratyayaiḥ abhinirvartita 🔽iti
translated: Nor does the body think, I am produced by these conditions.

analyzed: atha ca pṛthivī ādi dhātubhyaḥ cetanebhyaḥ cetanā antara anadhiṣṭhitebhyaḥ ṅkurasya evam kāyasya utpattiḥ
translated: Moreover, the body of a sprout arises from the elements such as earth, which are insentient and not controlled by anything sentient.

analyzed: saḥ yam pratītyasamutpādaḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt na anyathayitavyaḥ
translated: This dependent origination, being seen, should not be altered.

analyzed: tatra eteṣu eva ṣaṭsu dhātuṣu yā eka saṃjñā
translated: In these six elements alone, there is the notion of one,

analyzed: piṇḍa saṃjñā
translated: the notion of a mass,

analyzed: nitya saṃjñā
translated: the notion of permanence,

analyzed: suḥkha saṃjñā
translated: the notion of pleasure,

analyzed: sattva saṃjñā  pudgala saṃjñā
translated: the notion of a being,🔽the notion of a person,

analyzed: manuṣya saṃjñā
translated: the notion of a human,

analyzed: mātṛ duhitṛ saṃjñā
translated: the notion of a mother and daughter,

analyzed: ahaṅkāra mamakāra saṃjñā
translated: the notion of I-maker and mine-maker.

analyzed: sā iyam avidyā saṃsāra anartha saṃbhārasya mūla kāraṇam
translated: This ignorance is the fundamental cause of the accumulation of the evils of saṃsāra.

analyzed: tasyām avidyāyām satyām saṃskārāḥ rāga dveṣa mohāḥ viṣayeṣu pravartante
translated: When there is this ignorance, formations such as attachment, aversion, and delusion operate towards objects.

analyzed: vastu viṣayā vijñaptiḥ vijñānam
translated: Consciousness is the manifestation of objects.

analyzed: vijñānāt catvāraḥ rūpiṇaḥ upādāna skandhāḥ tat nāma
translated: And from consciousness arise the four form skandhas, which are name.

analyzed: tāni upādāya rūpam abhinirvartate
translated: Based on those, form is produced.

analyzed: tat aikadhyam abhisaṃkṣipya nāmarūpam nirucyate śarīrasya eva kalala buddu da ādi avasthāḥ nāma rūpa saṃmiśritāni indriyāṇi ṣaṣ āyatanam
translated: Combining those together, name-and-form is stated. The faculties mixed with name-and-form in the body are the six sense bases, in the states of kalala, budbuda, etc.

analyzed: nāma rūpa indriyāṇām trayāṇām saṃnipātaḥ sparśaḥ  sparśāt vedanā sukha ādikā
translated: The coming together of the three, name-and-form and the sense faculties, is contact.🔽From contact, feeling arises, such as pleasant feeling.

analyzed: vedanāyām satyām kartavyam etat sukham punar mayā iti adhyavasānam tṛṣṇā bhavati
translated: When there is feeling, the determination This pleasant feeling should be experienced again by me is craving.

analyzed: vāc kāya ceṣṭā bhavati
translated: From that, appropriation arises, which is the activity of speech and body.

analyzed: tatas bhavaḥ bhavati asmāt janma iti bhavaḥ dharma adharmau
translated: From that, becoming arises. Because of this, there is birth. Becoming is the dharmas and non-dharmas.

analyzed: tad hetukaḥ skandha prādurbhāvaḥ jātiḥ janma  janma hetukāḥ uttare jarā maraṇa ādayaḥ
translated: The appearance of the aggregates caused by that is birth. Birth is birth.🔽The subsequent old age, death, etc. are caused by birth.

analyzed: jātānām skandhānām paripākaḥ jarā
translated: The maturation of the aggregates that have been born is old age.

analyzed: skandhānām nāśaḥ maraṇam
translated: The destruction of the aggregates is death.

original: mriyamāṇasya mūḍhasya sābhiṣaṅgasya putrakalatrādāvāntardāhaḥśokaḥ /🔽tadutthaṃ pralapanaṃ hā mātaḥ /
analyzed: mriyamāṇasya mūḍhasya sa abhiṣaṅgasya putra kalatra ādau āntardāhaḥ śokaḥ  tad uttham pralapanam hā mātar
translated: The internal burning of the deluded one who is attached to wife, children, etc. while dying is sorrow.🔽The lamenting arising from that, such as Alas, mother!

analyzed: hā tāta
translated: Alas, father!

analyzed: hā ca me putra kalatra ādi iti paridevanā
translated: Alas, my wife, children, etc. is lamentation.

analyzed: pañca vijñāna kārya saṃyuktam asādhi anubhavanan duḥkham
translated: The experience of suffering accompanied by the activity of the five consciousnesses is suffering.

analyzed: mānasam ca duḥkhāt daurmanasyam
translated: And mental suffering is sorrow.

analyzed: evañjātīyakāḥ ca upāyāḥ te upakleśāḥ gṛhyante
translated: And such things as these are taken as secondary afflictions.

analyzed: te mī paraspara hetukāḥ
translated: These are mutually causal.

original: janmādihetukā avidyādayo 'vidyādihetukāśca janmādayo ghaṭīyantravadaniśamāvartamānāḥ santīti tadetairavidyādibhirākṣiptaḥ saṃghāta iti /
analyzed: janma ādi hetukāḥ avidyā ādayaḥ vidyā ādi hetukāḥ ca janma ādayaḥ ghaṭīyantra vat aniśam āvartamānāḥ santi iti tat etaiḥ avidyā ādibhiḥ ākṣiptaḥ saṃghātaḥ iti
translated: Ignorance and the rest are the causes of birth and the rest, and birth and the rest are the causes of ignorance and the rest, revolving ceaselessly like a potter's wheel. Thus, the aggregate is projected by these ignorance and the rest.

analyzed: tat etat dūṣayati tat na kutas
translated: This is refuted by him (Bhāviveka): No, why is that?

analyzed: utpatti mātra nimitta tvāt iti
translated: Because they are the causes of mere origination.

original: ayamabhisaṃdhiḥyat khalu hetūpanibandhaṃ kāryaṃ tadanyānapekṣaṃ hetumātrādhīnotpādatvādutpadyatāṃ nāma /
analyzed: ayam abhisaṃdhiḥ yat khalu hetu upanibandham kāryam tad anya anapekṣam hetu mātra adhīna utpāda tvāt utpadyatām nāma
translated: The intention is this: Whatever effect is related to a cause, let it arise, because it arises in dependence on the cause alone, without depending on anything else.

analyzed: pañca skandha samudāyaḥ tu pratyaya upanibaddhaḥ na hetu mātra adhīna utpattiḥ
translated: But the aggregate of five aggregates is related to conditions, not to an origination dependent on the cause alone.

analyzed: api tu nānā hetu samavadhāna janmā
translated: Rather, it is born from the coming together of various causes.

analyzed: na ca cetanam antareṇa anyaḥ saṃnidhāpayitāsmi kāraṇānām iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that apart from a conscious being, there is no one else who can bring together the causes.

analyzed: bījāt aṅkura utpatteḥ api
translated: Even in the case of the origination of a sprout from a seed,

analyzed: pratyaya upanibaddhāyāḥ vivāda adhyāsita tvena pakṣa nikṣipta tvāt
translated: since it is related to conditions, it is included in the subject under dispute, and thus is included in the subject.

analyzed: pakṣeṇa ca vyabhicāra udbhāvanāyām atiprasaṅgena sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgāt
translated: And when contradiction is shown by the subject, there is the fallacy of over-extension, leading to the fallacy of the destruction of all inference.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be so.

analyzed: anapekṣāḥ eva antya kṣaṇa prāptāḥ kṣiti ādayaḥ ṅkuram ārabhante
translated: The final moments of earth and so on, which are independent, give rise to the sprout.

analyzed: teṣām tu upasarpaṇa pratyaya vaśāt paraspara samavadhānam
translated: But their mutual conjunction is due to the power of the conditions that approach them.

original: na caikasmādeva kāraṇātkāryasiddheḥ kimanyaiḥ kāraṇairiti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca ekasmāt eva kāraṇāt kārya siddheḥ kim anyaiḥ kāraṇaiḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that since the effect is produced from only one cause, what is the use of other causes?

original: kāraṇacakrānantaraṃ kāryotpādāt siddhamityeva nāsti /🔽na caiko 'pitatkāraṇasamarthaṃ ityanya udāsata iti yuktam /
analyzed: kāraṇa cakra anantaram kārya utpādāt siddham iti eva na asti  na ca ekaḥ pitad kāraṇa samartham iti anye udāsate iti yuktam
translated: Because the effect is produced immediately after the circle of causes, it is not established that it does not exist.🔽And it is not right to say that another does not act because not even one of them is capable of producing that effect.

original: nahi te prekṣāvanto yenaivamālocayeyurasmāsu samartha eko 'pi kārye iti kṛtaṃ naḥ saṃnidhineti /
analyzed: nahi te prekṣāvantaḥ yena evam ālocayeyuḥ asmāsu samarthaḥ ekaḥ pi kārye iti kṛtam naḥ saṃnidhinā iti
translated: For they are not intelligent beings, so they would not consider in this way: Since one of us is capable of producing the effect, there is no need for our presence.

analyzed: kintu upasarpaṇa pratyaya adhīna paraspara saṃnidhāna utpādāḥ na an utpattum na api a saṃnidhātum īśate
translated: But they are produced by the mutual conjunction that depends on the conditions that approach them, and they cannot not be produced or not be conjoined.

original: tāṃśca sarvānanapekṣān pratītya kāryamapi na notpattumarhati /
analyzed: tān ca sarvān anapekṣān pratītya kāryam api na nā utpattum arhati
translated: And the effect also, depending on all of them which are independent, should not be produced.

original: naca svamahimnā sarve kāryamutpādayanto 'pi nānākāryāṇāmīsate tatraiva teṣāṃ sāmarthyāt /
analyzed: na ca sva mahimnā sarve kāryam utpādayantaḥ pi nānā kāryāṇām īsate tatra eva teṣām sāmarthyāt
translated: And even though all of them produce the effect by their own power, they do not produce different effects, because they have the power to do so in that very place.

analyzed: na ca kāraṇa bhedāt kārya bhedaḥ
translated: And the difference of effects is not due to the difference of causes.

analyzed: sāmagryāḥ eka tvāt
translated: Because the totality is one.

analyzed: tad bhedasya ca kārya nānātva hetu tvāt tathā darśanāt
translated: And because the difference of that is the cause of the difference of effects, as is seen.

analyzed: tat na
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: yadi antya kṣaṇa prāptāḥ anapekṣāḥ sva kārya upajanane
translated: If the final moment is independent in producing its own effect,

original: hantānena krameṇa tataḥ pūrve tataḥ pūrve sarva evānapekṣāstattatsvakāryopajanana
analyzed: hanta anena krameṇa tatas pūrve tatas pūrve sarve eva anapekṣāḥ tad tad sva kārya upajanana
translated: then by this sequence, all the preceding moments are also independent in producing their respective effects.

original: iti kusūlasthatvāviśeṣe 'pi yena bījakṣaṇena kusūlasthena svakāryakṣaṇaparamparayāṅkurotpattisamartho🔽bījakṣaṇo janayitavyaḥ so 'napekṣa eva bījakṣaṇaḥ svakāryopajanane evaṃ sarva eva
analyzed: iti kusūla stha tva aviśeṣe pi yena bīja kṣaṇena kusūla sthena sva kārya kṣaṇa paramparayā aṅkura utpatti samarthaḥ  bīja kṣaṇaḥ janayitavyaḥ saḥ napekṣaḥ eva bīja kṣaṇaḥ sva kārya upajanane evam sarvaḥ eva
translated: Thus, even though there is no difference in being contained in the granary, the seed moment that is contained in the granary and is capable of producing the sprout through a series of its own moments,

original: tadanantarānantapavartino bījakṣaṇa anapekṣā iti kusūlanihitabīja eva syāt kṛtī kṛṣīvalaḥ
analyzed: tad anantara ananta pavartinaḥ bīja kṣaṇa anapekṣāḥ iti kusūla nihita bījaḥ eva syāt kṛtī kṛṣīvalaḥ
translated: that seed moment should be produced as independent in producing its own effect. In the same way, all the subsequent seed moments that exist after that are independent. Thus, the farmer would be successful even with the seeds placed in the granary.

analyzed: kṛtam asya duḥkha bahulena kṛṣi karmaṇā
translated: What is the use of the farmer's laborious agricultural work?

original: yena hi bījakṣaṇena svakṣaṇaparamparayāṅkuro janayitavyastasyānapekṣāsau kṣaṇaparamparā kusūla evāṅkuraṃ kariṣyatīti /
analyzed: yena hi bīja kṣaṇena sva kṣaṇa paramparayā aṅkuraḥ janayitavyaḥ tasya anapekṣā asau kṣaṇa paramparā kusūle eva aṅkuram kariṣyati iti
translated: By that seed moment which is to be produced through a series of its own moments, that series of moments would produce the sprout independently even in the granary.

original: tasmātparasparāpekṣā evāntyā vā madhyā vā pūrve vā kṣaṇāḥ kāryopajanana iti vaktavyam /
analyzed: tasmāt paraspara apekṣāḥ eva antyāḥ vā madhyāḥ vā pūrve vā kṣaṇāḥ kārya upajanane iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said that the final, middle, or preceding moments are dependent on each other in producing the effect.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ na kiñcid ekam ekasmāt sāmagryāḥ sarva saṃbhavaḥ iti
translated: As they say: 'Nothing comes from one, everything arises from a collection.'

analyzed: tat ca idam
translated: And this collection

analyzed: samavadhānam kāraṇānām vinyāsa bheda tad prayojana abhijña prekṣāvat pūrvakam dṛṣṭam iti na acetanāt bhavitum arhati
translated: is seen to be preceded by an intelligent being who knows the difference in arrangement and purpose of the causes, so it cannot arise from non-intelligent [causes].

analyzed: tat idam uktam bhavet upapannaḥ saṃghātaḥ yadi saṃghātasya kiñcid nimittam avagamyeta iti  itaretara pratyaya tve pi iti
translated: This is what is meant by saying 'The collection would be reasonable if some cause of the collection were known.'🔽Even in mutual dependence,

analyzed: itaretara hetu tve pi iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is even in mutual causality.

analyzed: uktam abhisaṃdhim avidvān paricodayati nanu avidyā ādibhiḥ arthāt ākṣīpyate iti  pariharati atra ucyate
translated: Not knowing the intended meaning, he objects: 'But it is implied by ignorance and so on.'🔽He replies: To this we say.

analyzed: yadi tāvat iti
translated: If, first of all,

analyzed: kim ākṣepaḥ utpādanam
translated: is impulsion the production [of the effect]?

analyzed: āhaḥ jñāpanam
translated: Or is it the intimation [of the effect already existent]?

original: tatra na tāvat kāraṇamanyathānupapadyamānaṃ kāryamutpādayati / kintu
analyzed: tatra na tāvat kāraṇam anyathā anupapadyamānam kāryam utpādayati kintu
translated: In that case, a cause does not produce an effect that is not otherwise possible, but rather

analyzed: sva sāmarthyena  tasmāt jñāpanam vaktavyam
translated: by its own power.🔽Therefore, it must be said to be intimation.

analyzed: tathā ca jñāpitasya anyat utpādakam vaktavyam
translated: And in that case, another must be stated as the producer of what is intimated.

original: tacca sthirapakṣe 'pi satyapi ca bhoktaryadhiṣṭhātāraṃ cetanamantareṇa na saṃbhavati kimaṅga /🔽punaḥ kṣaṇikeṣu bhāveṣu /
analyzed: tat ca sthira pakṣe sati api ca bhoktari adhiṣṭhātāram cetanam antareṇa na saṃbhavati kim aṅga  punar kṣaṇikeṣu bhāveṣu
translated: And that is not possible without a conscious supervisor, even in the case of a stable [world], let alone in the case of momentary things.

analyzed: bhoktuḥ bhogena api kadācid ākṣipyeta saṃghātaḥ
translated: Again, the aggregate might be projected by the enjoyment of the experiencer, even in the case of momentary things.

original: sa tu bhoktāpi nāstīti dūrotsāritatvaṃ darśayatibhoktṛrahiteṣviti /
analyzed: sa tu bhoktā api nā asti iti dūra utsārita tvam darśayati bhoktṛ rahiteṣu iti
translated: But he shows that the experiencer is far removed, saying in things devoid of an experiencer.

original: api ca bahava upakāryopakārakabhāvena sthitāḥ kāryaṃ janayanti /
analyzed: api ca bahavaḥ upakārya upakāraka bhāvena sthitāḥ kāryam janayanti
translated: Moreover, many things existing in the relation of the benefited and the benefactor produce an effect.

analyzed: na ca kṣaṇika pakṣe upakārya upakāraka bhāvaḥ sti
translated: And in the case of momentariness, the relation of the benefited and the benefactor does not exist.

analyzed: bhāvasya upakāra an āspada tvāt  kṣaṇasya abhedya tvāt anupakṛta upakṛta tva asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because an existent is not the locus of benefit.🔽Because an instant cannot be benefited or harmed, as it cannot be altered.
